author: {'steamid': '76561198054005124', 'num_games_owned': 73, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1645766301}
review:
Giving this another shot, and I still find some of the facets frustrating to manage.
I still stand by most of what I previously said in older reviews and posts.
This is a micro-manage-y logic puzzle themed with trains, and having flawless timing when departing trains is how you win.

My major issues:
- One-off mistakes are unforgiving and many situations can only be fixed by restarting (if you're going for objectives).
- Income is inconsistent given the random nature of which kind of train spawns and what it's payoff is.
- Tax system is super inconsistent and the rate varies widely depending on the level. Tax rate depends on the speed at which the months fly-by and how much is paid. Some levels increase tax cost gradually over time.
- Tax system encourages minimal spending in effort to stay away from bankruptcy and as such slows down the pacing.
- The cost to remove necessary obstacles can be far too high.
- Game has too much RNG on how obstacles are placed and what kind, order in which stations spawn, what type of train spawns, and how much the train is worth.
- Sending additional trains is sometimes a gamble when the train's delivery is worth less than what was paid to summon it. e.g. Paid $2,250 for an additional train for it to only pay $1,700 when it arrived at a station.
- I still argue for an undo button because misclicks happens, but this being a logic puzzle game, the devs have their reason against it.

I have to say I definitely don't recommend this game because of the above mentioned, and because Train Valley 2 by the same dev corrects most of these issues. TV2 Passenger DLC brings back the same gameplay here but with a better rail-editing system and currency system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029903975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 10307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1636323332}
review: Its a nice looking game at a very reasonable price that hits the spot. Text, which can be important to your goals is often too small. I didn't see a way to make the text larger or bolder. Sometimes you want to click on a switch and you end up clicking on the stop the train button because that button is pretty big. Things are a little cramped but I'm going through it now on my second time and its more fun and playing better too. You can reset your progress with the click of a button in settings. That's a nice feature that is missing in a lot of games. Definitely buy it and buy a copy for a friend if its on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561199094551096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1611437985}
review: This game is deceptively cute. I got it because I like trains, but it gets pretty hard pretty fast. It pays to practice levels in sandbox mode beforehand to test the optimal track layout. The trains move agonizingly slowly, but one wrong turn and the terror of an air traffic controller on 9/11 sets in. It is not a relaxing game, but I thoroughly enjoy it nonetheless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066783339', 'num_games_owned': 791, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1091, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1091, 'last_played': 1610075230}
review:
What a nice surprise!

I like to bounce between genres and this game looked like a nice light sim to unwind and relax.

And I have a thing for trains. Don't judge me...

Although the game has basic only two mechanics, it uses them in great depth. In a scenario you'll lay track and manage your trains. You can also control the speed the time goes by and request additional trains to show up. Them trains will apear and need to go to different towns. Your job is to connect the towns laying track and manage when the trains depart and control their routes, simple. 

Each level has 3 bonus objectives, and going for them (specially all 3 in one go) can be a nice challenge. This combined with the speed toggle, makes for some nice scenarios. Playing at 1x speed with several trains at once and micromanaging everything feels very different from playing at 4x speed and just trying to get everything routed and going smoothly. 

All in all the game surpassed my expectations and I look forward to play the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202529859', 'num_games_owned': 1686, 'num_reviews': 2354, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1609528659}
review:
ACHIEVEMENTS:
39 Achievements ranging from easy to moderate in difficulty.

TRADING CARDS:
12 Trading cards

PROS:
-Addicting
-Fun and entertaining
-Chuck Norris achievement
-Gameplay

CONS:
-None as of yet

GAMEPLAY:
Great gameplay. If you ever owned a train track set then you will appreciate how these tracks fit together.

VISUAL EFFECTS:
Top-down view with pretty decent graphics. Everything is clear and distinguishable.

AUDIO:
Music has a good tone to it. Maybe for some the music might get annoying after a while, but I enjoyed it.

STORYLINE:
There is no real storyline in this game, but it works great without one.

REPLAY VALUE:
Very high replay value

PROBLEMS/ISSUES:
None - No problems installing game. No issues during start up. No game freezes, or unexpected quitting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060528934', 'num_games_owned': 980, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1639, 'last_played': 1608603174}
review:
Iâ€™ve picked up this game on a rim a while ago as I wanted to play a puzzle game. Turns out this was more of a real time micromanagement game and I loved it. The graphics are good, the music fits and I just love listening to the sounds of the trains. When playing it, you donâ€™t have to complete all the challenges on your first run, but if you can get all three at once, it feels so good. Not to mention going for the achievements can be a challenge but it's doable.

Also the DLC is nice as itâ€™s an entire level added in with unique features in each level. I would recommend playing the game first before buying the DLC in case you donâ€™t end up enjoying it but if you are a fan of micro management

author: {'steamid': '76561198039812292', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 2408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1710112426}
review:
Relaxing building of train tracks. Ok if you want to be 100% successfull it is not so relaxing. But game gives you fun.
Kids love it - but when they play in way to direct you which train you should sent where and where to build trains etc it gets heptic.

So if you like puzzles (you need to plan where to put rails...), trains it is definitely for you. If you have kids then it is must have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018060191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1606764560}
review: This game needs switches!!!!! The only build tool you have is tracks, and switches are made by the direction you pull or push your mouse in. It seems damn impossible to make anything more than a 2 rail switch, can't for the life of me get 3, don't expect there will ever be bridges or turn tables.

author: {'steamid': '76561198405836527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1618646367}
review: Addicting! Give it a chance and keep playing. It's challenging but once you figure it out, it's basically like an RTS. The game makes you think in different ways and I appreciate that! Once you figure out the basic strategies, you feel confident and can easily handle early game. Mid to late game is harder, one slip up can cost you one of the three challenges every level has. You don't have to do all the challenges in one go but it's more fun to be an overachiever! I have lost track (pun intended!) of time while playing it, and I have a big smile on my face when I get the timing perfect and get trains to just barely miss each other. I've already gotten more than I expected out of it and would highly recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043572089', 'num_games_owned': 357, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1622995969}
review:
A fun puzzle game where you lay out railway tracks and juggle dispatching trains to their destination stations (avoiding crashes and incorrect arrivals) all whilst you are gradually sapped of money. Run out of money and you lose the game!

Pleasant enough graphics and with a fair amount of levels to play in. Definitely worth it if you like simple train management games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167630101', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1605038804}
review:
Very stressful game. I was hoping for a relaxing experience: no. I gave up after 79 minutes and countless train crashes.
I reached level 5, tried a few times and could not succeed. I did not like the game mechanics: build tracks, decide when to make trains leave and keep clicking on arrows to try to avoid crashes. This is NOT a sim game, more like an arcade game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052989462', 'num_games_owned': 4711, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1605022607}
review:
A fun and surprisingly enjoyable strategy based puzzle game that is easy to jump into.  Train Valley has a nice aesthetic and the soundtrack is non-intrusive to your experience.  
You can challenge yourself if you are trying to get all three stamps or have a more casual experience if you are just trying to get through the level without going bankrupt (ends the round).  
Overall a nice experience 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198105785707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 332, 'playtime_forever': 865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1602897344}
review:
This puzzle game is way too difficult, but it's not the good kind of difficult.

As you keep playing you realize it has a conception problem. The maps are way too tight and cramped and don't give you enough room to maneuver.
The game starts handing your ass to you as early as the third level and it only gets worse from there. Not funny.
Even if you git gud at the game, the endgame isn't even that interesting. You just spend your time micro-managing trains on the track, stopping and moving them until the end of the level.

The main problem is that the game doesn't know if it wants to be a simple twitch puzzle game or a complex train simulation game and it sorts of sits halfway through, too fast to enjoy the world building and too complex and clunky to play fast.
In most maps you get repeatedly interrupted because of bankruptcy. Why does the game want me to manage money like that when it's not even realistic in the first place? (The trains take several month for each travel but you get to pay taxes at the end of each year)
A lot of annoyances like that can force you to restart the level for a very little mistake, losing half an hour of progress in the blink of an eye.

The User interface is also very bad and annoying and cause for many mistakes.

[h1](follow my curator page [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33882793/]GenXPlayers[/url] for more retro and indie reviews)[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197981604953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1921, 'last_played': 1597822142}
review:
One of the most fun puzzle games out there. The core concept is smart and it can be as relaxing or as difficult as you want (with pauses and speed controls.) You'll find yourself working on train timings and loop design. There are about 25 levels in all which are all pretty good. At the end of it you may find yourself wanting a tougher challenge and the DLC is there for that. 

The only con is there is some RNG in that the next station to open up (or bridge, tunnel, etc.) is not clear. While it adds level variety which is very nice, this isn't a game that you'll be replaying 20 times, but maybe twice. What made it frustrating was that the variation and unpredictability made some challenges very hard to solve because your super smart solution that you figured out after the last try no longer works. Is it a deal breaker? No not at all. Is it frustrating to not have to do more than 10k damage and the trees this time around spawned so you can't build your loop without losing the challenge? Yes. But we are talking about 2 levels of the 25 where this was an issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011668758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1416, 'last_played': 1643957355}

author: {'steamid': '76561198154190604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1597677684}
review:
I fully completed this plus its Germany DLC within 17 hours so it's not a game you'll get tens of hours out of, however it is a fun puzzle game that justifies its price tag.

Pros: Very nice difficulty curve, first level is very easy and the last level is pretty tricky, and the game layers in mechanics very well to increase this curve. Game is aesthetically pleasing (menu not so much) and the soundtrack fits well.

Cons: Some mechanics aren't so "difficult", but just cheese. In the DLC levels, a plane can just come out at any moment, bomb the exact square of track right in front of your train, or even worst, bomb your actual train, and that's it: you lose because of something out of your control. Other difficulty mechanics work much better. Also, the game is genuinely a "click here to load this level up" type game, no back story or other gameplay. It's a pure puzzle game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121112670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 278, 'playtime_forever': 1479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1596843376}
review:
Train Valley is a pretty straight-forward train game.  Beat it in 10 or so hours using a mouse.  Difficulty is easy-moderate.  Good game for kids.  

There are really only three things you do in this game: 
1. Lay/remove tracks
2. Tell trains to move, stop, or turn around
3. Determine which tracks the trains go on by clicking on the rail switch

There are also three speeds you can go if you find the trains too slow.  And there's a nice pause button in case everything is too crazy.  You can lay or remove tracks while the game is paused.


The music is charming, the game play and 'stamps' you can earn keep you on your toes, and I had no issues playing.  Did find it funny that Detroit was in a desert, so locations aren't exact or anything.  But for what it's worth, Train Valley is fun and will happily eat your time away.

The only real downside I can come up with is that the last level, Germany, is Dlc for about 2.50.  Lame.

review:
Fun and fairly easy. Some fun achivements and weird areas to make tracks.
Just long enough, doesn't milk playtime and  in some areas you have to plan the tracking.

Great and chill game to play before bed, and I could listen to podcasts while playing so not much focus needed in terms of reading and and listening. Mostly it will be alright if the tracks are somewhat straight and planned.
Worth the price, DLC also recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198172016819', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1131, 'last_played': 1684689852}
review: Lots of content, a gentle difficulty curve that gets surprisingly high, and lovely graphics/controls. The music and sound effects give it a calming feel. What would be a stressful management simulation is actually a calming train game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198893329311', 'num_games_owned': 793, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1492, 'last_played': 1681075343}
review:
AT A GLANCE:
     5/5 Stars - Buy it, buy it, buy it! Such an amazing game! Very well done! Fun, and entertaining for the whole family.

GAME GENRE:
     Single Player, Casual, Puzzle, Strategy, Simulation, Building, Family Friendly, Top-down

GAME DESCRIPTION:
     Release Date: Sept. 2015 - Build railroads connecting cities, and keep the trains on schedule. Set in different historical periods in countries such as Europe, America, USSR, and Japan (The DLC is set in Germany). Each level, within these countries, has its own criteria that has to be met.

KID FRIENDLY:
     (First know that I am very strict on kid approved material. A game with a standard rating of "PG" I might rate "PG-13". These are my ratings and have nothing to do with standard ratings)

     I rate this "G". Absolutely set your kids in front of the TV with this game they will be there for hours. Love this title for its family friendliness!

ACHIEVEMENTS:
     39 Achievements ranging from easy to moderate in difficulty.

TRADING CARDS:
     12 Trading cards

PROS:
     -Addicting
     -Fun and entertaining
     -Chuck Norris achievement
     -Gameplay

CONS:
     -None as of yet

GAMEPLAY:
     Great gameplay. If you ever owned a train track set then you will appreciate how these tracks fit together.

VISUAL EFFECTS:
     Top-down view with pretty decent graphics. Everything is clear and distinguishable.

AUDIO:
     Music has a good tone to it. Maybe for some the music might get annoying after a while, but I enjoyed it.

STORYLINE:
     There is no real storyline in this game, but it works great without one.

REPLAY VALUE:
     Very high replay value

PROBLEMS/ISSUES:
     None - No problems installing game. No issues during start up. No game freezes, or unexpected quitting.

WORDS FOR DEVELOPERS:
     What an amazing game, thank you! Can't wait to try the next one! Keep them coming!

CURATOR:
     If you like my reviews please follow my Curator page. Thank you! :)
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37878480/

review: Delightful little game. Gentle pace, and I really dig the puzzle aspect of it. Just intricate enough to catch my attention, but not so complex that I feel like I'm doing multivariable calculus. The challenges can be quite difficult, but I'm never wanting to pull my hair out in frustration, even if I don't succeed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021643308', 'num_games_owned': 1343, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1635996246}
review:
It's not a bad game, I couldn't get into it but not the fault of the game itself.

I thought it was more open, like a train builder not a puzzle game. Either or they locked the open world sandbox mode behind a bunch of forced 'story' which tbf, I don't really want to play through.

Price is dirt cheap so worth it for a try to see if you like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984735449', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1342, 'last_played': 1690435824}
review: This was an unexpected joy to play. I don't normally play time/resource management games, but this one had enough puzzle going on that I was thoroughly engrossed for hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040735667', 'num_games_owned': 1074, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 1974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1615499160}
review:
I may be mentally impaired, I don't know why railway systems and train tracks fascinate me this much, but Train Valley captivates me. A connect-the-dots game where your lines have a chance of crashing and burning without constant oversight. It really is as simple as getting trains to their stations either before they crash into each other, or before the value of their cargos depreciate to nothing, and I enjoy watching each one chug along on their journey.

I put this game off for a long time assuming that it was a train sandbox simulator, but I discovered there was a campaign, for which every map had secondary objectives beyond "avoid bankruptcy". It was dismaying to discover that stamps didn't unlock after completing a level (if you hadn't already met their criteria before the level's deadline) and opting to continue it, such as stamps for scheduling additional trains (i.e. spawning extra trains to increase profit) couldn't be completed because the game stopped allowing me to use the additional train scheduling function in continuation of the finished level. I can't say for sure, but it seems like you have to earn all 3 stamps for a level at the same time lest you need to replay it and see that the stamps don't stay unlocked permanently - that was my experience, at least.

I would recommend a train management game like this if the sound of a game like this doesn't instantly bore you, what you see (on the store page, or perhaps in gameplay videos) is what you get.

review:
Good Puzzle game. I found it rewarding whenever I completed a mission.

The learning curve is good, maybe on the easy side.

Sometimes there was some frustration.  I also found it isn't the type of game I could play for a long period of time.  I had to take a break in between.

Sometimes you have to learn how to create the optimal route for the map provided which you only learn once all the stations are placed, so there is trial and error. No story line.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129771193', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 303, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 797, 'last_played': 1591402463}
review:
Thoroughly enjoyable puzzle type game.

Pros:
- Enjoyable background music and sound effects
- A variety of trains with different speeds, lengths, and styles
- Cute, colourful graphics
- Levels start relatively easy and get progressively more difficult at a good rate, but don't get too difficult
- You can pause time in the game, which makes later more hectic levels much more manageable. Similarly, you can speed up time when things are too slow

Cons:
- The main menu doesn't show you what the goals for each level are, it just gives you a stamp for each one completed. If you want to see what goal you haven't done you need to start the level.
- What's the point of the annual tax? It seems to exist solely to make bankruptcy possible.
- The bankruptcy mechanic is infuriating. If you spend most of your money you should be able to wait for the next train to give you more, but if it's too slow then annual tax will mean you go bankrupt and have to restart the level. 
- Rogue trains. These trains appear and and promptly leave stations with no warning instead of queueing up and waiting for you to start them. It's accompanied with a special jingle. This can easily mess up an entire level forcing you to start again to achieve the goals. Thankfully they seem to be very rare.

Verdict: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198000138298', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1300, 'last_played': 1591981947}
review:
Quite the simple, relaxing and fun little game.
Got it to play with my little kid and found myself wanting to complete all levels myself.

This is simple to learn but provides quite the challenge after you learn it.
It's a puzzle game, as you need to find better and better ways to build your tracks and has a management aspect, as you need control the train trafic properly and efficiently. 
I appreciate this as I found it a good tool for kids to learn planning and priority concepts.

review:

Fun puzzles, fairly relaxing, good for short sessions.

Recommended on discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198804352528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1510, 'last_played': 1579897649}
review: Great game for those who are able to manage several things at once. The goal is to get trains to their stations, but you have to switch the tracks, build the tracks, and make sure there are no collisions. There are also different goals for each level that include not stopping any trains, only spending so much money, and more. I eventually got to the point where it is too hard for me, but I'm sure I will eventually pass the level. Amazing and challenging game. Definitely would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014629088', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1629391780}
review:
Que es Train Valley? a simple vista es algun juego casual de puzzles, pero no , va mas allÃ , es el videojuego que todo niÃ±o deseÃ² en su infancia, es aunque no lo parezca un reto a la mente, pero de cierta manera y no logro entender el porque despierta algo de infancia, me transporta a los 90s, no entiendo porque este juego lo logra pero realmente es una pieza muy bien ella, minimalista pero puntual, exacta y plena. 
Sii te gustan los puzzles, quieres pasar un rato entrenido y relajarte de la puta vida, es train valley tu juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198849222888', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1260, 'last_played': 1643508441}
review: Love this game. Relaxing soundtrack, almost-retro graphics, nice UI, great replay value (at least if you're a freak like me who needs to have every stamp). What I really love about this game is that your successes, failures, and everything in between are a natural consequence of what you do with an incredibly simple tool set (i.e. build track, delete track, switch junctions). It's not a game that plays tricks on you. Its cards are on the table, except when a STATION opens up on TOP of your track, interrupting it and causing crashes. This is my one complaint, and once you know where every station goes, it is easy to avoid. All of my other failures have been my fault alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972979016', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1126, 'last_played': 1588116415}
review:
Je recommande le jeu, mais avec des rÃ©serves !! (que je dÃ©taille ci-dessous)

GAMEPLAY : amusant, mais vite rÃ©pÃ©titif (voir plus bas). Un peu addictif quand mÃªme, car on a envie de rÃ©ussir les objectifs.
GRAPHISMES : suffisants pour ce que c'est. C'est un petit jeu de gestion qui tourne sur n'importe quel PC : il ne faut pas trop en demander aux graphismes.
DURÃ‰E DE VIE : ~20h (hors DLC Allemagne)
SCÃ‰NARIO : quasi-inexistant. Une trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨re mise en contexte historique (aspect des trains et des villes), mais c'est tout.

Le principe est simple : construire des voies de chemin de fer et aiguiller les trains pour qu'ils arrivent dans la bonne ville. Il faut donc gÃ©rer au mieux l'itinÃ©raire des voies, puis l'orchestration des trains, pour que tout le monde arrive Ã  bon port, le plus rapidement possible et sans accident. Tout Ã§a en gÃ©rant votre budget : construire des voies, ce n'est pas gratuit !

CÃ´tÃ© gestion, on ne gÃ¨re finalement pas grand chose. Les villes apparaissent toutes seules et vous n'aurez aucun contrÃ´le sur leur croissance. Vous ne choisirez pas la gare de destination des trains, ni la gare d'arrivÃ©e. Vous pourrez simplement contrÃ´ler, dans une certaine mesure, le moment de leur dÃ©part. Vous n'aurez pas non plus la possibilitÃ© de construire des ponts ou des tunnels : ceux-ci apparaissent tous seuls, dans les scÃ©narios qui le nÃ©cessitent. Il n'y a aucune automatisation possible (ma plus grosse dÃ©ception), tous les changements d'aiguillage sont rÃ©alisÃ©s manuellement. Et ce sera mÃªme une part importante de vos actions dans le jeu.

Votre objectif principal sera toujours d'Ã©viter la banqueroute (le dÃ©couvert sur votre compte en banque), ce qui mettrait fin Ã  la partie. Dans 5 scÃ©narios sur 6, vous aurez Ã©galement des objectifs secondaires Ã  remplir : Ã©viter les accidents, ne pas faire d'erreur de gare, gagner une certaine somme d'argent, etc.

AprÃ¨s quelques parties, on se rend vite compte que, dans 90% des scÃ©narios, la voie en forme d'anneau avec des entrÃ©e/sortie pour chaque gare est ce qu'il y a de plus efficace. Ã€ partir de ce moment-lÃ , le jeu consiste Ã  se demander "comment vais-je pouvoir construire un anneau dans cet environnement ?". Une fois que c'est fait, un peu de concentration suffit pour terminer les objectifs. Quelques petites nouveautÃ©s/difficultÃ©s apparaissent en fin des saisons 3 et 4, mais rien de bouleversant pour le gameplay.

Vu le prix, Ã§a reste un petit jeu trÃ¨s intÃ©ressant !! Il m'a fallu 18h pour terminer les 4 premiÃ¨res saisons de la campagne, avec l'ensemble des tampons (donc, pour ainsi dire, finir le jeu) : Ã§a occupe quelques soirÃ©es !
Je suis pourtant loin d'avoir rÃ©ussi tous les succÃ¨s Steam, donc je pourrais y passer quelques heures du plus si je voulais peaufiner un peu. Par contre, point que je trouve trÃ¨s limite : un grand nombre de succÃ¨s n'est rÃ©alisable qu'avec un DLC (la saison 5 : Allemagne).

Le descriptif du jeu dans le magasin mentionne un mode "AlÃ©atoire", que je n'ai pas trouvÃ©. C'est un peu abusÃ© !
Je soupÃ§onne que ce mode ne soit disponible qu'aprÃ¨s avec fini la saison 5, pour laquelle il faut acheter le DLC. C'est sur ce point que porte ma plus grosse rÃ©serve ! Certes, le DLC ne coÃ»te pas cher, pas Ã§a reste frustrant de dÃ©couvrir qu'il faut une rallonge pour dÃ©bloquer certaines fonctionnalitÃ©s du jeu...

Le mode "Bac Ã  sable" prÃ©sente trÃ¨s peu d'intÃ©rÃªt. Il permet de rejouer un scÃ©nario de la campagne sans contrainte de temps ou d'argent. On peut s'en servir occasionnellement pour tester une circuit de voies, sur un scÃ©nario un peu difficile. Perso, je ne m'en suis servi qu'une fois. Et Ã§a ne m'a pas franchement aidÃ©.

En rÃ©sumÃ©, un petit jeu sympathique, mais avec pas mal de dÃ©ceptions en cours de route. Il ne tient pas toutes ses promesses. Mais j'ai quand mÃªme pris plaisir Ã  y jouer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1587978607}
review:
Train Valley is a cartoony puzzle game where you create railway lines by dragging the mouse pointer between various points of interest on premade maps.   Work out the optimal routes and then run trains to make money and achieve the objectives for each level. 

This really looks and feels like a mobile game.  While the developers put a lot of effort in here, they seem to have completely missed the target audience by releasing the game on PC (although mobile app stores have heaps of these kinds of games, they still might have made some money).   The gameplay is really too simple on PC considering it's up against heavyweight transit simulators like Cities in Motion.   It might be good for kids to play, but I can't see myself recommending this one to other gamers, although I will give some kudos to the developers for building a well polished game that does meet the minimum requirements for any PC game.   Another game where it would be nice if Valve gave us a "maybe" option.

Edit: Actually, no maybe option here.  The developers, in the true spirit of mobile devs, stamped out an identical sequel, except with the #2 next to it, yet they still left this old deprecated version on Steam to try scam people out of money for a product they superseded.   That's just pure greed.  Thumbs down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170191703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1582, 'last_played': 1587936906}
review: Train Valley is a highly addictive, engrossing and rewarding puzzle-solving train game (with very light elements of train simulation). The campaign is a good length (26 hours including all achievements) and the difficulty and game progression clips along nicely. Trying to complete all of the challenges to collect all of the stamps on all of the levels was a personal highlight from my time playing. On the most challenging of levels these had me shouting out in equal parts exasperation and mirth as one train inevitably clips the back of the train in front whilst trying to squeeze the most out of the narrowest of margins. Very fun, highly recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561199032345241', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1869, 'last_played': 1587140946}
review:
Ok, I wonâ€™t be able to tell you about that if I wouldnâ€™t give it a try, and it is surely worth a couple of euros on sale, but the truth is that if youâ€™re not under movement restriction due to COVID 19  or similar reasons you should not play that game.
Beyond its slick graphic and logic addictive railroad project management task there are a lot of hidden works.
First of all, drawing the track is not easy. Playing grid is inaccurate and if by chance youâ€™re crossing the railroad not yet built it fail to keep on and you have to start from scratch.
The game, against what seems before buying it, is much more on switching the railway exchange rather than projecting the track. 
On top of that, bankruptcy is more than an option especially in the very first games â€“ sometime timing estimation about money seems harder than the getting trains safely to the right place, they also did an award for that.
Finally, it overheats the hardware and it really seems strange since far more complicated and graphics sophisticated games didnâ€™t â€“ at least not that much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081200078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1091, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1633784659}
review:
So at first, I though this was some kind of boring childish train game, but then I tried to play a few levels and I was surprised. 
I started on high speed and it was pretty difficult. My trains always crashed and I couldn't look after all of them at once. My rails were a mess and I couldn't keep up with all of it.
It was really fun learning how to handle all the situations at once and build good rails.
I got it on sale and it was really worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198375136685', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1587036075}
review:
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Train Valley Ã¨ un puzzle gestionale in cui il giocatore dovrÃ  soddisfare le richieste degli innumerevoli livelli: pianificando con cura la costruzione di binari e ferriovie, rimuovendo ostacoli e cercando di evitare scontri fra locomotive, che nello sfortunato caso andranno a distruggersi, danneggiando il tracciato. Comprando i treni e potenziandoli sarÃ  possibile trasportare il carico verso le giuste destinazioni, che potranno a loro volta restituirci dei prodotti lavorati da consegnare altrove.

[h1]Comparto Tecnico[/h1]
Il gioco Ã¨ sviluppato su Unity in 3D, la grafica Ã¨ sufficiente ma un po' grezza. Le impostazioni grafiche permettono solo di ridimensionare l'interfaccia.
L'audio Ã¨ semplice e la colonna sonora un po' ripetitiva.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015838512', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1586802644}
review:
Good game, not revolutionary or anything like that, but you will get good value for your money.

+interesting puzzle game
+each level feels somewhat fresh, even if it plays mostly like previous levels
+it's fast (I've been playing basicly entire game on max speed with active pause), so if you mess up and want to start over, it won't put you too far back timewise
+it's cheap

-feels like some features are not clearly communicated, I found out that you can stop a train halfway through last season of the base game
-sometimes obstacles obscure your rails, it is not common, but possible that the arrow to select direction will be beind a building so it's hard to say where it is pointing towards

review: Quaint little puzzle game, but I keep getting fucked over in the early game of maps because trains keep launching randomly before I've even set up a second track. Considering the whole gimmick of the game is to be essentially the traffic controller, it's a little difficult to actually stop trains from colliding when they won't even wait until you can lay down a second track before setting off on the one rail that's actually laid down directly into a head-on collision with another train.

review:

Il vous faudra optimiser vos lignes malgrÃ© les obstacles, gÃ©rer votre portefeuille entre revenus, dÃ©penses, et taxes, et faire partir vos trains le plus tÃ´t possible sous peine de se retrouver dans une impasse. La moindre erreur d'aiguillage peut ruiner votre progression dans le niveau.
Sous ses airs de maquette et de jeu pour enfant, le titre se rÃ©vÃ¨le prenant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982771744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1584241091}
review:
A fun game, but not very big (you can easily play through every level in 1-2 hours) and doesn't keep me coming back like Train Valley 2, which is a great game. I still recommend TV1 for an hour or two of entertainment, but I recommend TV2 more enthusiastically, and would say TV2 is worth a much higher price. TV2 also has a DLC that adds 20 levels with the 'people movement' objectives of TV1. I would also recommend the TV2 'people movement' DLC over TV1.

In TV1 and TV2, the gameplay is the same: lay track, dispatch trains according to demand, make money for successful arrivals. In TV1, you basically just build your track and wait for notifications to pop up showing you where trains need to go. In TV2, you move more freight than people, which ends up making for more complex objectives and more thoughtful planning of train schedules because you can better identify future route demand rather than it being random.

Why do I recommend Train Valley 2 so much more? Laying track in Train Valley 2 feels more polished, there are a lot more levels, there is much more complexity/variation in later levels and it feels more satisfying to replay a level just to get the 5-star score in TV2. This amounts to a game that has much more playtime in it: you could keep coming back and probably play 30-40 hours of TV1 before getting bored of it as opposed to 1-2 hours for TV1.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014941814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2399, 'last_played': 1706455827}
review:
I've bought this game for my kids, and ended up finishing it myself, chasing for most of the achievements. It's fun little puzzler that requires a lot of concentration and multitasking on the last levels, particularly if you want to get all the bonus goals. The graphics are nice and do the job, the soundtrack can get a bit annoying though. 

It is also one of those games that you can just boot up for a short 15 to 20 minutes game, as it doesn't require any warming up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078293150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1585466429}
review:
Fun puzzle train game. Nice graphics, intuitive gameplay, challenging train routing puzzles. If you love trains, building tracks and solving complex train routing puzzles this is a great game to try.

The developers are still around and even this late after release just implemented interface fixes for 4k screens so you can properly see and use the scaled interface. Really well done.

review: Simple, easy to grasp rules and concepts that lend themselves to a pretty robust overall game. It's just a mixture of money management, track position, track directions, and train timing, but it all comes together to be a very enjoyable mixture of time management and strategy. Excellent to play just a couple of games, or to gorge all at once while you try to get all 3 achievements for each stage.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983234769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1584849808}
review: its fun. puzzle difficulty range from fun to annoying (i kept failing making a good layout for a couple levels and looked up solutions on the internet). the difficulty ramp up is nice, as well as having sandbox mode as an option for every level. most of the levels are short which is a plus if you don't want to have to put a big chunk of time aside. but it can get addicting to try and finish a level with a perfect score, or attack the harder achievements. visual theme is neat, music is good and after 12 hours i still enjoy it.

review:
A mostly relaxing, though sometimes stressful, mix of puzzle, time management, simulation, and a maze-like game. It is fun in short sessions with 3 varying goals most levels. There are 4 sets of 6 levels in the main game and another set as DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198221346776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 971, 'last_played': 1692564732}
review:
It's a very interesting, exciting, frustrating and challenging game!! 
The concept is so simple yet it's very challenging if you want to do it right and complete all the challenges! 
Surely recommend this. It is based on levels, so you can jump in for half an hour to relax, or to challenge yourself one step at a time.
I got hooked so hard .... Love a challenge! 

Genre: puzzle solving

author: {'steamid': '76561197988534641', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1842, 'last_played': 1682107914}
review:
I honestly didn't think this game was going to be as challenging and entertaining as it really is.

What started as "Yeah... I'll give it a shot" ended in hours of frustrated but satisfying railway planning and conducting.  The challenges are hard but obtainable for each level and the game paces itself from sometimes being "Oh this is easy" and relaxing to ":LKJHA:OINJA:OUINJ:LDKNS:!@@@@@!!!!!!!!" and you finish by the skin of your teeth.

If you are a fan of puzzle games, it's a fun strategic one.  If you don't really like puzzle games... you might start to after this.

review:
What looks like a fun managment game is actually an RNG nightmare.
you have little to no control over track placement because of the map layouts and trains tend to randomly just start going even if a another train is arriving at that station.

To many frustration moments beyond my control to recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034402756', 'num_games_owned': 3370, 'num_reviews': 369, 'playtime_forever': 5406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5392, 'last_played': 1624015305}
review:
A fun management/puzzle train-themed game! Direct trains to their wished destinations, and lay the tracks! Choo choo! 

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
In Train Valley you must direct trains from one station to another. Typically the levels don't have any tracks built yet, so you have to construct them. Building costs money, and you don't start with enough to connect everything. Delivering trains earns money, but the reward is lowered with time. Delivering trains also develops the city connected to the station, which enables the station to produce faster trains. You have the ability to spawn extra trains, which you want to do generally nonstop to maximise income. But that can be tricky, and my big downfall of creating too many trains! If all stations are occupied with waiting trains, the trains depart on their own. 

[h2]My memories post Train Valley 2[/h2]
I have played TV1 quite a while ago, I just completed TV2 and thought my review needed an update. So it's mostly memories and not a fresh playing experience. And those memories are fun. The levels, the 'ding' sound of new train spawning, the juggling of trains, it's a very fun game! 

[h2]TV 1 or 2?[/h2]
They look similar on gameplay, their name suggest an evolution of some sort, but they play very differently. TV1 focuses on managing the trains, TV2 is a pure puzzle to create products via a construction train. TV2 has upgraded visuals, workshop support plus a big friendly community, while TV1 has a deeper discount. I recommend both games, however if you want to create maps or participate in friendly weekly competitions, I recommend TV2!

This one is a classic in my book! 

86/100

review: It's been a while since a played a game in its entirety! Train Valley is definitely up there with my favorite management games. Not too complex, but not at all boring either. In Train Valley you build.. - you guessed it - rail networks. Each of the 24 levels has its own challenges. To enjoy this games, challenge yourself to go for a perfect result each time. Make sure you don't crash trains, go bankrupt or miss any other mission objectives. I can't wait to get Train Valley 2 and the Germany DLC!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034546374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1576885691}
review:
Consiste en poner vias entre las estaciones, darle la salida a los trenes y jugar con los cambios de via para llevar a cada tren a su estaciÃ³n. Â¿Facil, no? No exactamente... Tienes un presupuesto y las vÃ­as cuestan dinero, de modo que vas a querer optimizar cuanto dinero gastas compartiendo tramos de vÃ­a. Cuando tengas dos o tres estaciones y un tren o dos serÃ¡ fÃ¡cil de controlar, cuando tengas seis o siete estaciones y cuatro trenes, la cosa cambia. Oh, Â¿dije que dabas la salida a los trenes? Te vas a reÃ­r... los trenes tienen un horario. Si no les das la salida tu, saldrÃ¡n cuando llegue su hora. Tanto si la vÃ­a esta libre, como si no.

Es un reto de coordinaciÃ³n a la altura de pocos. Un puzzle sencillo de aprender, pero realmente complicado de dominar. Me he sorprendido reiniciando un nivel para terminarlo sin perder ningÃºn tren (aunque no fuese requisito para continuar). Va directo a favoritos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118391762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1574793426}

author: {'steamid': '76561197988846326', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 1038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1574708408}
review:
To be able to gain 100% achievements, You need to buy Germany DLC. 

The game offers two game modes: classic and sandbox. [spoiler]I know the game description says there's 3rd one but I couldn't find it or they simply ment last level of each page. [/spoiler]

The game revolves around You, building train rails from one station [spoiler]location of stations is pre-determined and only appear in random order)[/spoiler] to another and if necessary, guiding those, as well as managing crossroads if any will be made. There is 5 pages (one is DLC) and each page contains 6 levels, where last level has random generated obstacles and the only goal is to succesfully complete the level. All other levels have 3 side-objectives, which can be done separately, making it a little more difficult. I've counted only 1 frustrating map, all others are pretty much cool.

Graphics and music is simplistic but it catches your ear.

I've encountered two bugs, which make your trains explode, one randomly just because and one where trying to reverse train, while it stands on too many crossroads, might cause a boom. It happened maybe like 6 times in total so not much when taking total time into consideration.

Sandbox mode is just removal off time limit, objective, cash and most of random events from any map, making player controlling everything as they please. Boring to me but I know people who enjoy this.

Amount of time You can spend on this is assuming You like to abuse pause and play only on x4 speed:
Beat the game: 10hours or less (if You do not care for achievements and stamps)
All stamps: ~12hours
All Achivements: ~15hours
If You do not like to speed up the game and rarely use pause, probably can be enough for even 30-40hours.


It's relaxing game and I totally recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047941314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 964, 'last_played': 1574196026}
review:
A Puzzle-Strategy Train Simulator that I found really entertaining.
Good graphics, good gameplay, good sound in overall.
There are 24 (30 if you buy the Germany DLC) easy/medium and chill levels.
Some levels have different strategies too which made the gameplay feel less "repetitive".

For the ones who aim for the Maniac Vandal and the Mega-Railroad achievements, I had an easy time in 2-6 (Chapter 2, Level 6).

Anyway, I definitely recommend the game. 
10â‚¬ (13.50â‚¬ if you want all the DLCs) are way enough for at least 7-10 hours of fun.
There is a demo version too if you just want to try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000963037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1573346287}
review:
Wasn't a huge fan. The sort of just-in-time micromanaging that this game requires equates to more stress and frustration than it does fun. If you like chaotic, on-the-seat-of-your-pants management, I'd say give it a go. If you're more of a TTD, set-it-and-forget-it style of transport fan, steer clear or at least wait for a sale.

Update: Instead, check out the sequel, Train Valley 2! It fixes this problem and has a beautiful graphics update.

review: Fun little puzzle/train game. You play through it rather quickly, but I do recommend you get it if you find it on sale. The game works flawlessly on my GNU/Linux Ubuntu 18.04 system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103071995', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1573600462}
review:
Very addictive puzzle-strategy game. Starts fairly easy, but gets quite complex, especially in the last of the four countries. Comes with a few challenges per level and lots of achievements. Graphics and sountrack feel a bit outdated but that does not affect the fun at all. Can fully recommend!

EDIT: Bought the Germany DLC, it's also very fun - not too hard - and introduces a few interesting twists.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014518234', 'num_games_owned': 1604, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1578966356}
review:
Way more frustrating than it needs to be.

The small maps and simplistic design elements are good and relaxing, but it's hampered by what seems to be an unfocused vision. What results is a game that is neither a challenging puzzle game, nor a relaxing chill-out game. The amount you can manipulate the game world is far short of a management sim -- you can only lay tracks and flip switches -- and yet the hostile bankruptcy mechanic is eager to cut short any relaxing experience you're trying to get out of the game.

There is no save/load functionality for individual puzzles, either, making the endless mode pointless really -- you can make a really nice train system, but for what? 

Furthermore, the devs either don't understand or are unreceptive to criticism -- see the steam discussion thread about the bankruptcy mechanic -- which means that Train Valley 1 feels like a shell of a game, and Train Valley 2 seems not to have learned any lessons from this.

It was fun, for awhile, and I really wish it would live up to that potential, but it doesn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025840813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5689, 'last_played': 1597884277}
review:
For the 2 or 3 dollars I paid for the game it's absolutely brilliant. I've been playing in bursts, rage-quitting when I oh so very nearly aced a level, having failed to juggle multiple trains on the crazy spaghetti railways I'd strewn across the landscape. Next day I'll have another crack at the level. A couple of them have been fairly challenging to complete the 3 objectives (Don't Crash Trains, Don't Stop Trains, Don't Bulldoze Too Many Things etc).

I've been playing at 60fps 4k monitor with a 6gb GTX 1060 and an i5-4570. The first time you start the game choose 1080p, set the interface scale slider to max, then restart in 2160p.

Oh... rather embarrassingly I didn't notice you can reverse a train's direction until yesterday...

author: {'steamid': '76561198042335794', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1571419369}
review:
I like trains and love little powered train models.
I can build tracks, send trains, manage them - a lot of fun.
Graphics and music is nice, has character. Levels are different enough, side quests sometimes really challenging and I can always just play level continuously after finishing it, or hunt high score.
Sometimes I play on favorite level on never ending mode for 15+ minutes on top speed - stressful and relaxing at the same time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198410169156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 485, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1554238912}
review: If you are expecting a model train simulator where you build tracks then sit back and delight at your new setup, you will be out of luck. This is more of a puzzle game where the levels get progressively harder requiring careful placement of track, switching of track points and above all ensuring that each train gets to its designated station without crashing into other trains. You will need to be quick thinking and plan ahead. This game does have the frustration factor so be prepared.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189899943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1570502699}
review:
Este es de esos juegos muy del estilo de Nintendo: Un concepto sencillo pero divertido con el que puedes pasar jugando durante horas y horas.
Es tan simple como ir del punto A al B y tienes que trazar la lÃ­nea para que ambos puntos se conecten Â¿en dÃ³nde radica la dificultad? que tambiÃ©n aparece el punto C y D y aquÃ­ comienza la locura porque cada estaciÃ³n te pide un destino y tienes que ser rÃ¡pido y organizado apenas teniendo un momento para organizar todo en tu mente antes de tomar la decisiÃ³n de hacer partir los trenes, en un momento dado el punto C quiere ir al A, el A quiere ir al D, el B quiere ir al C y el D quiere ir al B, y si te demoras mÃ¡s de la cuenta los trenes parten solos, PERO ademÃ¡s tienes la dificultad que tienes que cambiar los recorridos de las lÃ­neas que tu mismo trazaste para que los trenes lleguen al destino que te piden.
Un juego liviano que no pide recursos ni rams, solo trabajar el musculo de tu cerebro.

author: {'steamid': '76561198333441331', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1573098466}
review:
[b]Fazit nach 77 Minuten[/b]
Eigentlich wollte ich nur kurz reinschauen, bevor ich ins Bett gehe (es ist jetzt 06:40). Das Endergebnis lautet: Europa ist durch. Auf allen 5 Maps sind alle 3 Aufgaben gemeistert und die abschlieÃŸende Mission wurde mit einem Kontostand von $106k beendet. Prima .. Zwei Bier sind auch weg. Aber ok. 

Ich habe bisher nichts zu meckern und muss sagen, dass es doch recht fesselnd ist. Die ersten Missionen waren alle mit dem ersten Versuch erledigt - nur bei der letzten habe ich mich 3 bis 5 Mal verzettelt und musste neustarten. Soweit ist der Schwierigkeitsgrad also auch fÃ¼r relativ Denkfaule wie mich noch gut zu schaffen. 
Die Grafik geht in Ordnung und hat ihren eigenen Charme. Das einzige Manko war bei mir die GrÃ¶ÃŸe des HUD bei FullHD-AuflÃ¶sung .. es schrumpft doch schon recht deutlich. Vielleicht sollte man hier eine etwas niedrige AuflÃ¶sung wÃ¤hlen. 
Der Sound ist zweckmÃ¤ÃŸig. Verschiedene Loks geben bei der Abfahrt verschiedene TÃ¶ne von sich (ob sie sich noch in Geschwindigkeit o.Ã„. unterscheiden, ist mir leider entgangen) und die Hintergrundmusik dudelt gemÃ¤chlich vor sich her. GestÃ¶rt hat soweit nichts.

Der erste Eindruck nach dieser doch recht kurzen Spielzeit ist durchweg positiv. Das Spielprinzip ist leicht zu verstehen .. ein bisschen Tutorial in den ersten Missionen hilft Ã¼ber niedrige EinstiegshÃ¼rden hinweg. Die 1,49â‚¬ waren bisher top investiert und ich kann jedem nur empfehlen, dem Spiel im Sale eine Chance zu geben, wenn man derlei Knobelspielen nicht ganz abgeneigt ist. Ob es auch die knapp 10â‚¬ wert wÃ¤re, wird sich in den nÃ¤chsten Runden zeigen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991556719', 'num_games_owned': 681, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1570200768}
review:
This is a puzzle game which is train-themed. The only thing that comes remotely close to managing trains is flipping the switches on time. There are no resources, no passengers, no upgrades for trains and no way to build your own stations (you can only lay out track). On top of that, it is difficult to tell the flow of a track once there's a train on top of it. 

Was expecting more, got less. Not recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000896253', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 212, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1558456287}
review:
If youâ€™re in the market for a puzzle game, check this one out, itâ€™s regularly on sale for like Â£1. Train Valley is a puzzle game taking place on maps where coloured train stations are spawned and you have to lay the tracks down for the trains. You then have to get the coloured trains to the corresponding stations.

It sounds simple, but the maps are short and littered with obstacles. The faster you get a train to the station the more money you get, and you need that money for track-laying and demolition work. Also, thereâ€™s an annual tax for each level that whittles down your cash to keep you on your toes.

On the maps, as the years go by, youâ€™ll see more modern trains. Each successful train arrival builds new additions to the map, expanding a city or factory or whatever. There are four â€˜seasonsâ€™ taking place in various countries over the years. America, Europe, Russia and Japan. If youâ€™re a history nut you might see some historical moment â€“ Japan for example has the building of the Yamato Battleship and the Winter Olympics and Football World Cup. The first two scenarios are cakewalk, but Russia and Japan are quite difficult, particularly Russiaâ€™s WW2 scenario.

Anyway, simple, but tricky puzzle game, if thatâ€™s your thing, check this one out. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198353746924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1568526547}
review:
Great little Train Sim Game.
Fun for a few hours, more like a logic-fun-puzzle game than a train simulator.

I would like to see bigger maps, some signals and automatism.
Think it could evolve into a nice little train sim from its actual mini-game character.

What is not so fun, since the map is always just one screen and the trains get bigger/faster to the end, the game gets near to impossible in some endgame maps. But still okeyisch, and fun to start with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007353824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1566996871}
review:
I would definetely give this game a sideways review if I could.

This is definetely not the worthy successor to RT3 we've been waiting for all these years.  It is a game about controlling trains and making them get to to their destination without crashing into each other.  I recommend trying out the demo or even buying it on sale and refunding it if you don't evjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014763908', 'num_games_owned': 2519, 'num_reviews': 331, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1564307280}
review:
[h1]Preamble[/h1]

A very good train simulator where you manage several trains and their tracks to different stations and try your best to avoid collisions.

Difficult to play, very hard to master and get perfect levels. It is very addicting and has several hours of gameplay for only 10$, [i]or your regional equivalent[/i].

The base game has 4 seasons with several levels/missions in each season and 1 DLC Season, Germany.

The latter levels are [b]very[/b] difficult to even complete, let alone getting 3 stars on them and you will definitely go through trial and error many times.

If you despise games where you need to attempt the same level several times to complete I'd just stop here and move on, because you will use a lot of time on re-doing levels due to your own failure.

I wouldn't say playing this game in hour-long sessions at a time is the best. I enjoyed it more by playing about an hour at a time.

[h1]The gameplay and mechanics[/h1]

The trailers of this game depict the gameplay perfectly.
You create tracks, preferably as efficient tracks as you can, and send trains from Point A to Point B. Early levels are quite easy, they are more of a tutorial to learn you the game, but once you advance just 1 season you will be forced to focus a lot more on efficiency of your tracks and keeping everything organized.

The game has 4 gameplay speeds that you can switch between, Normal speed, x2 times, x3 times and Pause. The pause button is extremely useful as sometimes you just have to pause for a second and get a real overview of the entire situation because it's so hectic.

Graphics are obviously one of the least important things in a game like this, but the graphic style is nice and pleasing as you can see in the trailers.

Later levels introduce new mechanics(off-screen trains, bombings and more complicated track management).

[h1]Things I'd like to see improved[/h1]

You build tracks, you build a lot of them.
The way the track-building system works does not reflect this. The way it is works makes it seem like you just build a few tracks so they just quickly threw the system together and didn't bother spending too much time on perfecting it.

What do I mean by this?

I mean that it just... doesn't work properly.

Several times you will find yourself having to destroy the last part of a track because it didn't go where you wanted it to go on the very last part. It is difficult to explain with words, I really don't know how, but it is very apparent that it could've been improved upon by a lot, especially considering that the track-building is a very big part of this game.

[h1]Ending words[/h1]

All-in-all I think this is a great train management game. It is very difficult to master, and once you do you will be very proud of yourself, and rightfully so!

It is not a giant, super-complex train sim. It is a bit more minimalistic in terms of the mechanics that are present, but in it's own right it is a great, difficult game.

I'd pick this up if it interests you, it is not a bad game at all, just keep in mind that it is a bit more on the minimalist side in the grand scheme of train sims.


[h1]Curator page[/h1]

[i]If you liked this review or otherwise found it helpful in deciding whether or not to buy this game, feel free to follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/29162366/]my Curator page[/url].[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197967459119', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1564844092}
review:
Railroad simulators are nothing new. It's a well explored genre so any new comers need to be bringing something unique to the table. If anything, Train Valley takes away from other, better, railroad simulating game. 

The core problem with Train Valley is the gameplay. There is very little choice in Train Valley. The only thing you do is place track, switch tracks, tell trains to leave the station, or tell them to stop/turn around. That's it. There are no buildings, there is limited financial management, you don't have any say as to which trains will spawn in what station, & you will be doing this over and over again for some 30+ nearly identical levels. There is little distinguishing one level from another other than some static terrain challenges. Some areas are either impossible or more expensive to build track over but other than that level 5 plays like level 20. 
Each level has some challenges you can accomplish and while they can be tricky it doesn't give you a sense of satisfaction having completed them.

Graphically it's soothing. The music is repetitive but not obnoxious. It runs well and I suppose if you are into a relaxing experience this might work. But compare this to a game for iOS/Android called Trainyard, whose level of complexity is ten times more interesting and more fun. Train Valley feels like [i]it[/i] should be on mobile platforms, and even then it'd still be a bore.

Ã€ travers les diffÃ©rents niveaux, on devra gÃ©rer les aiguillages et le trafic ferroviaires avec que tous nos petits trains se rendant Ã  la garde correspondante dans les temps impartis, tout en s'assurant que le moins d'accidents possibles n'ait lieu. Mais trop d'accidents, trop de voies construites trop rapidement, et c'est vite la banqueroute de notre entreprise. Et il faudra toujours rester aux aguets. review:
I can't tell if Train Valley is one of the hardest puzzle games I've ever played or if I'm just really bad.

10/10 would recommend if you can handle the stress of things happening outside of your control.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044271358', 'num_games_owned': 531, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1562884937}
review: I'm not a huge puzzle game guy but this one was decent. It's very similar to PolyBridge in that you are given an amount of money and have to get vehicles (in this case trains) to their destinations. I like how you sort of end up making the puzzle for yourself to solve, as you create your rail network and have to figure out how to get all of your trains where they're going. I'm pretty bad at this game, but I stilled enjoyed my time with it. If you like trying to figure out how to get your traffic to work in games like Cities:Skylines, you'd probably like this game. It does, however involve A LOT of MICROMANAGEMENT. The later levels are definitely not chill. Would recommend for fans of puzzle and/or train games.

review: Do you like trains? Do you like puzzles? Do you like levels that start out easy and slowly build to a stressed-out zen state of flipping rail switches and juggling trains, only to be interrupted when you mess up and your trains crash? Do you enjoy telling yourself 'okay, this time I'll get it' over and over again? Then this game is for you. It's definitely for me, anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140146180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 2137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1982, 'last_played': 1562530654}
review:
A very entertaining, and occasionally even amusing, game.
Not much I can tell you about whether it is for you or not, that isn't already revealed by screenshots, trailer or zapping through a gameplay video. But I will point out some borderline points that may otherwise hold you back from making a purchase;
+ Notice that there is a demo available.
+ Gameplay is intuitive and smooth. I found no annoyances with interface or controls, and there are assignable keyboard shortcuts to build, erase, pause and speed.
+ Gameplay (puzzle) elements are introduced gradually and are paced perfectly.
+ You can make (some) changes while the game is paused, meaning that you are almost certainly able to complete all levels with not many restarts.
+ Great value in terms of playtime;
++ I'd say minimum gameplay time to completion is 6 hours or so, but it's an easy 10-12 hours total for completing all "advanced objectives", which are what I'd call "meaningful", and not just random difficult things.
++ There are three additional objectives for all levels, such as completing the level without pausing, not letting a train into the wrong station, not rebuilding any track, etc.
++ Add additional replay value if you have a bit of "Hey, I can improve on that solution, let's try again" in you.
++ The final level in each of the four worlds is kind of a free-for-all where a point score is given, which you can attempt to improve on.
++ Overall I got 30 enjoyable hours out of the game before I was "done" (base game, ~3 hours of additional content in the German DLC).

10/10, would crash nuclear train again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037138875', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1086, 'last_played': 1561328326}
review:
A very enjoyable strategy/puzzle/management game. 

Simply put, you'll have to make way for trains aiming to go to different stations. 
Each train arriving at their destination will give you cash, which you can spend on new railways, maybe make a parallel line so you can have 2 trains going each way etc.. 
There's usually obstacles in the map that will block you way, some removable for (sometimes really high) cash, others unmovable, period (such as mountains).

It's simple enough to play, but can be really enjoyable to min-max your railways to make them efficient, and each stage having a set of 3 achievements definitely spices the challange, such as not being able to pause, or stop the trains. 

Definitely recommend it, specially at it's price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090084538', 'num_games_owned': 1320, 'num_reviews': 268, 'playtime_forever': 1545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1562910159}
review:
A polished semi-simple train & track puzzle-type game which is relatively relaxing and I recommend on deep sale to fans of puzzle & strategy games.  Here is what you need to know:
+Decent simple music and graphics fit the look & relaxed vibe of the game.
?Its a micromanagement puzzle: You build tracks, control track switches, choose when a train leaves a station, and can stop or reverse a train.  The latter may be limited with certain train types or levels, but that was never explained in-game.
?There are no notable differences between trains of different eras, nor can you choose between train types to deploy. You can only choose whether a train deploys early, which costs money because the sooner a train reaches its destination the more money you get.  That means...
?The way you earn money incentivizes you to be careful by either playing slow at 1x speed or by pausing periodically when laying track or pulling switches to make a path for a train.  This can become tedious or an issue with...
-There is no way to save your progress on a map/level which takes much longer than the advertised 5-10 minutes (normal mode) if you feel the need to stop the game at all, even if you run the game at 2-4x speed when unpaused.
+The map/terrain often evolves over time - The more time passes, the more buildings or things get added to the map that you may want to destroy later. So building many tracks early may decrease bulldoze costs in the long term.
?Out of all the levels, there are only a few map/terrain specific events like the rocket launch in the Store page's trailer.  Those are caused by train(s) that enter from the outside of the map using pre-existing track, all of which is equally as rare as the events they trigger.

review:
I quite enjoy this simple and relaxing puzzle game.
Not too mention trains are awesome!
It follows a fairly linear increase in difficulty through each level by adding new stations of various colours, but it creates a well balanced puzzle despite having such simple mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972900635', 'num_games_owned': 273, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1662747436}
review: I really enjoy this game. I won this in a contest and wasn't certain what to expect. Pleasantly surprised to find a simple puzzle game that is easy to hop into and fun to play.  For me, some of the stages have been fairly challenging, but their presented in way that I don't feel punished for not getting them right. Each stage is easy to start over if you noticed you made a mistake; and they aren't long so they feel annoying if you make a mistake later in the stage. I just found this game really relaxing to hop into an play during a work break to help reset my mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977461855', 'num_games_owned': 804, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1562256564}
review: Gioco molto carino per passare una mezz'oretta di divertimento. Sedetevi comodi, installate il gioco e preparatevi ad imprecare contro dei treni che vogliono partire quasi sempre dalle stazioni sbagliate. Ma alla fine il bello Ã¨ proprio questo: creare un percorso che permetta ai treni di partire e arrivare integri alla stazione di arrivo, evitando pericolose collisioni durante il tragitto. Un casual game molto carino adatto a chiunque, specialmente a chi ha sempre sognato di creare una piccola ferrovia. Da acquistare il prima possibile.

review: This is a fun, interesting, (sometimes) difficult game. It made me feel like a kid just discovering the pure joy of video-games. author: {'steamid': '76561198064494426', 'num_games_owned': 507, 'num_reviews': 682, 'playtime_forever': 1448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1577852389}
review:
easy enough to just get through, and the challenges are decent in difficulty. I find the icon at the station to dispatch a route to be small. played in a windowed screen really shows why the ui majority should be at the bottom, because in a panic you close the game than pause. A lot of time I am sure I launched a train from a station only for it not to register and mess with my timing. and I find as soon as one thing goes wrong those whole thing falls apart. It is fun and not forgiving. it can be as soothing as stressful.


also playing windowed if you drag the window to the top of desktop the game maximizes to fll screen, w10 os. with only a handful of achievements locked behind the dlc its not bad but a bummer for achievement hunters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991685583', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1561845442}
review:
This game sucks if you have any sort of lack of patience. The train speeds are juust a bit too random, change a little bit when they go between train types. For some reason tracks change direction when a train drives into a junction so the track is different for the next train so you can't keep structures. The train drawing track is a bit wacky, can go off screen for some reason. You don't get a timer for when the next train spawns, which makes buying another one early a bit odd. 

What this game did do was remind me of how much I love Mini Metro, which is easier to play and harder to master. Recommend that one a lot more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038880470', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1394, 'last_played': 1561812509}
review:
[h1][b]â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†[/b][/h1]
As expected, it's a small-time game meant to be played in 30-minute sessions. It is slightly too repetitive to run this game from start to end within a view days, because ultimately it's just a plate-spinner; all you do is making sure the trains reach their destinations while avoiding accidents, hazards and bankruptcy (e.g. game over). Each level has three optional stipulations which only build up toward unlocking achievements. Later levels pose challenges in a variety of ways, like managing a incoming trains emerging from offscreen, planes bombing the traintracks or working with or around structures on the map like bridges and mountains.

If all the above sounds like a mobile game to you - with the generic and aged artstyle - than I totally agree. It is just another game that you can play while watching or listening to something else. It's nothing insulting. It's best to get this during a sale (obviously) as the discount tend to pretty big on this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040657252', 'num_games_owned': 860, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1596135214}
review:
Train valley is a nice realxing puzzle game where you have to bring a train from the one to the other station. the stations are divides in colours. You need to build tracks to bring the train from the one station to the other, the danger is that the trains can collide, then you get no money form bringing it to the station and the railroad is damaged. the trains then dissapear. After a few hours i really like the game.

Good:
- High replayability
- many missions
- nice artstyle
- a game for the mister worldwides out there

Overlal a pretty nice fun game you should pick up for not too much money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139815184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1882, 'last_played': 1562251985}
review:
Excellent puzzle game, with a lot more content then I expected. 
Some of the levels are extremely challenging, especially in the later levels and the Germany DLC, and really make you think. It is both a nice way to unwind, and mindbogglingly frustrating all at once.

If you can pick this up on sale then I wouldnt hesitate, but even at full price it is completely worth the money.
