author: {'steamid': '76561198185081122', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1531552144}
review:
6/10.

fun for 6 or 7 hours, repetitive after . 

 Not to be compared with Train Fever or the likes, this is NOT a train simulation. It is not a deep game, you understand the rules in 30s. 

This game has more its place on IPAD or IPHONE even , than on a PC. this is really well done, but it misses some elements of Fun. Price for a game like this should be around 1$.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982210220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1468687496}
review:
Train Valley is a very good puzzle game about optimizing train routes, finding a balance in shared resources, and nail-biting micromanagement.

The levels play quickly, and the art (but not the gameplay) is a pleasant throwback to Railroad Tycoon 2. 

There is a whiff of "sameness" to the gameplay on each level, despite some randomization of station locations. This makes me think that Train Valley might do better in the mobile market. Regardless, it's inexpensive, and has a Demo available on Steam. If you enjoy puzzle games, give this one a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028655071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1452925707}
review: Short entertaining family game. Simple enough for kids, with difficulty that scales up to be challenging and fun for adults. The only cons are it is relatively short (like most family games) and in gameplay there is a reliance on frequently pausing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004202366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1276, 'last_played': 1618946401}
review: I absolutely love this game.  I bought it on a whim during a steam sale and I'm thrilled that I gave this game a chance and discovered this little gem.  You would think it would be super easy building a train track and getting the trains to the correct stations by switching the direction of the junctions, but it's more complicated then it seems.  I have been replaying all of the levels trying to get perfect scores on each so the game has tons of replayablity and I have no intention of putting the game away for a long time to come.   Buy this game as quickly as possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993772546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1610202012}
review:
When i bought the game i thought that it is a game to play in a casual way, without paying much attention. It isnÂ´t. It is a fucking time stealing machine. The gameplay is addictive, just one more level, just trying to get all stamps in the level... poof... 2h later. It looks simple, but in some levels you need to try over and over again until you find the best layout for the tracks and donÂ´t make a failure when managing the trains.

You will hate it or love it!

Des niveaux variÃ©s avec diffÃ©rentes difficultÃ©s Ã  surmonter jalonnent ce petit jeu trÃ¨s addictif.

Les graphismes sont trÃ¨s plaisants et illustrent plutÃ´t bien chaque pays traversÃ© et permettent donc de dÃ©couvrir de nouveaux univers Ã  chaque pays.

Gros bÃ©mol : le tutoriel explique trÃ¨s mal les outils et les enjeux. Les 5 premiÃ¨res minutes sont donc les plus difficiles, car on ne se bat non pas contre le jeu, mais contre l'interface. Le jeu en vaut la chandelle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087738131', 'num_games_owned': 797, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1955, 'last_played': 1467993826}
review:
Excellent game. It's very much about paying attention to details and good timing. 

I found that most of the levels were quite doable, but if you try to complete all three bonus objectives in a level some of them are quite challenging and took me more than a few attempts to win.

I would recommend that you watch Total Biscuit's WTF is video to get an idea of what the game is like.

The two things that would make this game better would be if there were even more of it, and if there was a level that had a crazy number of stations, say 12, on a fairly large map, with a really long time limit, so that you could get a more extreme experience of frenzied train management.

The German DLC is worthwhile I think, but it did not present as much of an increased challenge as I was hoping for, and there is a frustrating level where planes bomb your trains which feels more like luck than skill (but that's only one level in the DLC).

I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone that loved building a road and rail system in Sim City 2000, and who also likes time management games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124139802', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1468020032}
review: I had originally thought this was a simulation game, but (so far) it feels a bit more like a puzzle game. That said, I am really enjoying it and finding the levels challenging and a bit addictive. Worth having in your library for some casual, but tricky fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999498546', 'num_games_owned': 8364, 'num_reviews': 236, 'playtime_forever': 3244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3003, 'last_played': 1468150415}
review:
Train Valley has a simple premise. Bring Trains from one Station to another. But what the game makes out of this relatively simple premise is astonish. 
Why? Let me explain!

[h1][u]Gameplay[/u][/h1]
It all starts slow. Two Stations. One Train. The Interface is very intuitive and you will understand every function in absolutely no time. Of course the first mission is also a tutorial, so you will have no problem to get into the game mechanics. 

The game offers four chapters with six missions each. Also every mission has 3 â€œExpert goalsâ€ you can try to fulfill. These will change the way you play the mission, what is a motivation to play it again and reach them. But the final goal in every mission is the same. Get every Train that will spawn to their desired station without going bankrupt.
Bankrupt? Yes! Every train as a certain value assigned. As longer as the train needs to reach its destination it loses value over time till it is at $0. 

After the first two missions the difficult raises pretty quickly, but the Missions are never getting unfair. You will have the motivation to try it again and never have the feeling that you lost because the mission design was unfair. 

[h1][u]Programming[/u][/h1]
I had no crash in my whole play time or any stutters. The game ran smooth at any given moment. 


[b]Pros[/b]
-Motivating Gameplay
-Good tutorials
-Itâ€™s very easy to get into the game
-Motivating extra goals in each mission
-Two game modes. Classic and Freeplay

[b]Cons[/b]
-Difficult raises pretty fast
-The final mission goal is always the same


[h1][u]Final thoughts[/u][/h1]
I found this game only because Steam suggested it to me, and I am really glad about it. Train Valley really took me by surprise. At any time I was motivated to beat the actuall mission and reach as many bonus goals as I could. And when I failed I could see why I did. The price it okay for what you get. Even if you just play through it without playing for the Expert Goals you will need some hours till you beat the final mission. 
Even if you never played such a game, like I did, I can still recommend this to you if the screenshots and the trailer appeal to you.

review:
Un peu dÃ©Ã§u car je m'attendais Ã  un jeu de gestion, une sorte de remake HD de Railroad Tycoon... En fait pas du tout !

Dans son principe, ce jeu me rappelle beaucoup Mini Metro : les gares apparaissent spontanemment et alÃ©atoirement. Le joueur doit les relier entre elles et contrÃ´ler le trafic ferroviÃ¨re (envoyer les bons trains dans les bonnes gares tout en Ã©vitant les collisions). Bien sÃ»r, il y a de plus en plus de gares, d'aiguillages et de trains Ã  gÃ©rer, ce qui rend les niveaux de plus en plus rythmÃ©s et difficiles.

Pour conclure, mÃªme si ce n'est pas le style de jeu auquel je m'attendais, il reste amusant et m'occupera certainement 3 ou 4 soirÃ©es... pas non plus de quoi me rendre accro. Mais bon pour 10â‚¬, c'est correct.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169083424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1477050207}
review:
Placing a piece of track is a pain in the arse, thus making the higher speeds near impossible to play on. However, if you can get past the finicky track placement then you're in for something real, darn good.

Train Valley is essentially a management simulator. You're placing tracks, trying to get "blue train" from point "A" to point "B"; all while trying to complete other, level specific objectives (which are OPTIONAL). If you do manage to complete the level specific objectives, then you'll gain 3 stars. Yes, it's one of those games... This is actually one of the games' biggest advantages though, at least it is for me. I like trying to get all the OPTIONAL stars. I like trying to perfect each level to the best of my ability. So all in all, I think this is a great management sim. It's also very accesible/casual, so that's nice to people who are new to this type of game (like me).

So yeah, if any of that sounds interesting to you then you'll most likely enjoy this game. Just be warned that the track placement is not good, but it's not enough to break the game.

review:
Disclaimers: 
--Impulse purchase(perhaps unrealistic expectations)
--Only played about 30 minutes

Thought that it'd be more like other train games or non-train games that happen to have trains in them(potentially complex, some economy, logic puzzles, schedules, automation, etc; whereas, in this game you seem limited to building track and then pausing/starting the game to manually control train routing at track intersections, avoiding crashes). It looks good enough, but the gameplay is very simple.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995283923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1468100283}
review:
Good idea, and it's fun when it works. But the game has a few major flaws that makes it incredibly frustrating. There is a timer that appears only when there are 5 seconds left before the next train. If you have anything in that range, there's very little you can do especially when the levels are complex. I've also had tracks explode after a train runs into a mountain, even though the track is green when I place it. Further, I've had objects destroy tracks when they sprout from the ground.

I was enjoying the game for a while, but the glitches and train management is just far too frustrating for complex levels. I can't recommend the game until the developer fixes these issues, and revamps some of the track management.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062956563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1482364124}

10/10, will oroboros my train into itself again!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063327951', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1124, 'last_played': 1467204829}
review:
Keep in mind that this is a game about micromanaging trains, not a strategy/"tycoon" game. This game is quite fun, but quite short of you don't like completing all the challenges in the game.

I picked this game up during a Steam sale for â‚¬7.00 including DLC. I would say that it was worth that money, but I am not sure if I would recommend it at full price (â‚¬12.50).

Pros:
- The core mechanics, laying rails and directing trains, are easy to understand and work reasonably well
- The theming is great
- The levels are designed well, making it a challenge to find the optimal layout of tracks to complete all challenges
- The game is not incredibly difficult. The 6 levels added by the DLC are somewhat harder than the 24 in the base game. The ability to pause the game makes it a lot less stressful too.

Cons:
- The music is repetitive, and while soothing it just annoyed me after a while.
- Rail junctions work... weird. Rail junctions are blocked when a train is on top of them. However, the game also blocks rail junctions on adjecent rails, or even crossing rails.
- The challenges get stale after a bit. The challenges for Germany have some more fun ones in them, such as blowing up 5 trains.
- The sandbox mode is completely broken, with train stations not showing up at all. Besides that, it's not all that fun without a clear goal or even money to worry about.
- Even after completing every challenge, and completing every other achievement, I only built about 9000 train tracks towards the "build 10.000 train tracks" achievement. Luckily the game counts train tracks built just before restarting a level, so building a lot of useless tracks on a level with high starting money solves that problem, but "grinding building train tracks" is not fun nor won't it give me a sense of achieving something on reaching it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066022068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1467598732}
review:
This is a good game, but dont let the 90%+ recommended fool you, this is not a great game.

Its short, simple and at times rather frustrating. This is not a tycoon game in any way, this is just a puzzle game. Sound effects are repetitive, music is uninspired. 

That all said it is charming and a bit addicting. The puzzles are fun and keeping track of all the crossovers on a built up map can be challenging. Graphics are cute and give decent atmosphere to each level.

Not the Train tycoon game I was looking for, but a pleasant way to have some fun for a few dollars. Just dont go in with high expectations.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977047016', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 992, 'last_played': 1467168319}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043401618', 'num_games_owned': 1802, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 3249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3161, 'last_played': 1472937749}
review:
A perfect crossover between Pipe Dream and Flight Control HD.

You layout rails to bring a constant flow of trains to their designated stations. Very easy concept but gets hectic as more stations spawn around the map and the train numbers increase.

Each train you deliver will increase your money to build more tracks, and pay the taxes each year (which is very short in game time!). Trains lose worth fast, so don't deliver them fast and you risk going bankrupt.

You can also launch extra trains at a random location for a fee. Gamble on this option to increase your cash, but abuse it and you'll end up overloading your network which is certain to lead to disaster, or to fun!

Once you have multiple trains running between stations you'll need to micromanage switches and stop your trains if necessary (losing precious money) to avoid accidents which will always make your trains blow up violently; I think it must be explosives that you are delivering.

You can play the levels in a variety of styles. Spend loads of cash to build a huge rail network which can support loads of trains running at the same time. Or play it stingy and try to see how many trains you manage to circulate back and forth on a single narrow piece of track. Both methods have their risks and rewards.

Some of the later maps have special features, such as high speed trains that you cant control or stop, adding to the excitement.

The campaign is not extremely long, but you have sandbox levels at the end of each stage, and stamp challenges on each level also increase replayability. This can make some easy levels very challenging, for example play the level without using pause, without stopping any train, and launch 10 additional trains.

The game runs smooth and seamlesly performance wise, and hardly has any bugs. There are 4 (5 with DLC) countries which all have a pleasant and unique visual style, and the trains have some nice variety from around the world. You can see that the devs like their trains, even though this is a puzzle game, not a tycoon one.

Also the game still receives attention from the devs, patches, and DLC. At the really honest price tag this is sold I can not do anything but recommend Train Valley to everyone!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065680736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 834, 'last_played': 1644054780}
review:
Io ho sempre amato i treni, sin da quando ero bambino (non dimenticherÃ² mai il "Casimiro" del Film Dumbo!), e ho sempre sognato di possedere un diorama ferroviario tutto mio. A livello di videogiochi, tuttavia, vuoto: a parte SteamLand (che spero un giorno sarÃ  disponibile su Steam) ho sempre trovato molto piatto questo genere. Soltanto Train Valley ha avuto quella scintilla che mi ha fatto pensare "Wow, non so niente di questo gioco, ma lo voglio!"

Graficamente non c'Ã¨ male: lo stile Ã¨ minimale e geometrizzato come va ormai di moda da qualche anno, ma non avrete molto tempo per ammirare la grafica.

Per vincere i vari stage, bisogna condurre i convogli verso precise stazioni, e sei incoraggiato a farlo bene da due fattori: la possibilitÃ  di guadagnare piÃ¹ denaro portando i treni a destinazione il prima possibile, e la presenza di tre obiettivi per scenario. All'inizio sembra facile, quasi rilassante, ma giÃ  dagli ultimi stage del primo capitolo impazzirete per far andare tutto per il verso giusto, tanto piÃ¹ se volete raggiungere i sudetti obiettivi. Inoltre, Ã¨ molto piÃ¹ semplice perdere per bancarotta di quanto non voglia farti credere il gioco (Di per se le tasse annue sono piccole, ma i binari e le demolizioni hanno un costo -pesante, aggiungerei-, ed un incidente tra treni spesso si traduce in una sconfitta immediata).

Da comprare

author: {'steamid': '76561198041714386', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 839, 'last_played': 1574559279}
review:
Once I realized that this was primarily a puzzle game with Trains and not really a railroad simulation, I changed my expectations and enjoyed this game.  It is a fairly quick game, and it can be a challenge to track (pun intended) which switches are needed in what order for each train.  

The only thing I have trouble with are pop-up buildings that made it nearly impossible to see which way the switch was aligned.  Other than that, it works as advertised.

I enjoyed this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035374577', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1259, 'last_played': 1466870641}
review:
Train Valley ist ein nettes Gelegenheitsspiel fÃ¼r zwischendurch.
Es geht darum ein Streckennetz aufzubauen und ZÃ¼ge zu ihrem Zielbahnhof zu schicken. Dabei sollen mehrere Ziele und Aufgaben gelÃ¶st werden.

Das Spiel bietet insgesamt 4 Kampagnen mit jeweils 5 Missionen. Man kann sich auch eine weitere Kampagne als gÃ¼nstiges DLC dazukaufen. 
Die Aufgaben sind anfangs recht leicht, aber sie werden in den spÃ¤teren Missionen recht knifflig. Dabei sollen mÃ¶glichst keine UnfÃ¤lle gebaut werden und keine ZÃ¼ge zum falschen Bahnhof geschickt werden. Man muss ebenso stÃ¤ndig das Budget im Auge behalten, damit man nicht bankrott geht. Oft ist es schwer den Ãœberblick Ã¼ber alle ZÃ¼ge zu behalten, wenn viele gleichzeitig fahren und man ein komplexes Streckennetz hat.
Aber das ist genau der Reiz um das Spiel komplett durchzuspielen und alle Missionen vollstÃ¤ndig zu erfÃ¼llen. Ebenso um alle Steamerrungenschaften freizuschalten.
Durch die Aufgaben gewinnt das Spiel etwas an Abwechslung, aber es ist nach einer Zeit doch recht eintÃ¶nig. Trotzdem ist es ein recht kniffliges und nettes Spiel, das SpaÃŸ macht.

Positives und Negatives

+Nette Grafik
+Passende Soundtracks
+Viele Karten und Aufgaben
+Unterschiedliche ZÃ¼ge und Orte
+Keine Bugs oder AbstÃ¼rze
+Leichte Steamerrungenschaften

-Wenig Abwechslung

Wertung
80/100 Punkten
Ich gebe eine klare Kaufempfelung, vorallem wenn es im Angebot ist.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993180934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1651734164}

Wie der Name schon sagt, geht es in Train Valley um ZÃ¼ge. 
In verschieden Missionen mÃ¼sst ihr unterschiedliche Anforderungen erfÃ¼llen, wie Gewinnsummen erreichen oder unfallfrei handeln. Darin liegt die Abwechslung aber auch gleichzeitig die Einseitigkeit. Das Spiel sieht sehr schÃ¶n aus und ist sehr atmosphÃ¤risch und stimmig. 
Ich empfinde es als eine klare Kaufempfehlung!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024942939', 'num_games_owned': 1557, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 1542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1383, 'last_played': 1629822943}
review:
In a way, this is a sort of real-time puzzle game, not unlike Tetris. You lay a finite amount of track, attempt to make the best use of the limited space to deliver the most trains in the shortest time, and revise your track configuration as necessary.

The satisfaction of finding the right configuration is hard to describe. Let me put it this way: If you're the type of person who likes optimizing processes, such that an unexpectedly high workload can still be managed with nothing going wrong, you will find much to like in this game.

It is a heuristics development and revision game where learning the optimal layout for each situation is half the fun, and the other half is guiding trains through that layout with nothing exploding.

Though it usually has little bearing on gameplay, I should also say that this game uses locations and times from history rarely seen in videogames, especially the DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013097520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1813, 'last_played': 1659698157}
review:
I don't play tower defence games anymore, because I have this game instead. If you don't see the appeal to tower defence at all, this game is not for you. If you've got the tower defence itch, this game will scratch it until it bleeds.

This game doesn't have an undo button, so push your luck too far and it's game over. I know why that would put some people off, but it works for this game.

Why is this better than tower defence? In any good tower defence game, getting good at it means learning how the towers work and how each enemy type works. Once you've figured that out, there's not much left to learn or do.

With this game, the trains behave the same way (at different speeds) and the track laying rules are intuitive. Will you overpopulate your grid with trains to build up money, or will you play it safer with collissions, but risk facing bankruptcy? Can you time them perfectly so they almost hit but don't? What is the best configuration for the tracks? Is it worth paying extra to demolish your way through a shortcut? These dilemmas you get to face from game 1, without having to remember what does what.

There is only one change I would make to this game if I were the developer, and that is this: When the game is paused, I want to still be able to see which trains are going full speed and which trains have only started moving. As a father, I love a game that I can pause and come back to after a nappy change, but I often forget which trains are going full speed and which are not by the time I return.

review: TrÃ¨s simple d'accÃ¨s mignon et diablement addictif, j'ai pris la dÃ©mo et j'ai tout de suite accrochÃ©. Ca parait simple comme Ã§a mai sla pression monte trÃ¨s vite ! Comme une locomotive ! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198006652851', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1464902178}
review:
I've been looking for something to scratch the Transport / Railroad Tycoon itch for a while now, and although there are some potentially promising games on the horizon, it seemed like there were no good examples in the genre at the moment.

And then I stumbled upon Train Valley, which, within a few minutes of playing confirms that the above is true - this isn't a tycoon game.  What it is, is a puzzle game - and once you get a few levels in, it's fiendish.  It conjurs up the correct mix of raising a smile when things go to plan, and swearing at your screen when you get overwhelmed and the inevitable happens - and trains crash.

The premise is simple; you are given a grid and two coloured stations on each map, and you drag lines from one to the other, avoiding or bulldozing (at a cost) your way through buildings and trees, some of which are randomly placed whilst some are always in the same place.  Trains will spawn in the stations with a colour indicating that they want you to direct them to the other station, you click to launch the train and it makes its way down the track and you get paid when it arrives - each train has a value which ticks down from the moment it spawns to the moment it arrives at the destination.  The complexity comes in as the map progresses.  New stations will spawn on the map - in predetermined positions but in a random order, and begin to spawn trains all eager to go somewhere else.  You will lay more tracks, launch trains, and use the track switches to try and avoid a catastrophe.  Fortunately you can stop and reverse trains, but this doesn't always help if you're not keeping a good watch out - only one train can occupy a station, so it will launch itself if a second one is about to spawn.

The difficultly ramps up; early maps serve to teach you the basics and later ones cram stations in awkward places with choke points to force trains onto the same pieces of track.  When things go well, it's great - but sometimes, you just can't avoid an explosion.

Back to my search for a tycoon game - even though this clearly isn't one, the art style and simple way of laying track would lend itself very well to a more in depth strategy game which, if I were the developer, I'd seriously consider.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140710588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1637144422}
review:
Pour commencer, Train Valley nâ€™est pas Ã  proprement parler un simulateur de train, il sâ€™agit plutÃ´t dâ€™un jeu de type puzzle avec des trains. 
Les graphismes sont Ã  la fois simples, beaux et trÃ¨s clairs, ce nâ€™est pas du tout difficile Ã  dÃ©chiffrer comme dans certains simulateurs. 
Le gameplay est idÃ©al, on apprend Ã  jouer trÃ¨s rapidement sans passer par un tutoriel laborieux. Je regrette cependant qu'il n'y ai pas un compteur dÃ¨s le dÃ©but sur les trains au dÃ©part, on se fait parfois avoir car Ã§a ne s'affiche que sur les derniÃ¨res secondes. 
Vous apprendrez vite les combinaisons les plus efficaces mais le jeu a de nombreux dÃ©fis pour corser les choses, et le mode bac Ã  sable permet de s'amuser avec son imagination sans contraintes.

review:
I like this game although after you complete all of the levels there is not much left to do. 
Controls are easy and the game is easy to follow the tricky part of the game is having to focus your attention in multiple spots at once. You have to mannage all the trains and build tracks to where they are going. Luckily, you can stop trains and turn them around, though some levels require that you do not.  Overall, this game is fun and even a little challenging. 
The music for this game is also really nice and calming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025344376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2334, 'last_played': 1524786610}
review:
This game is frustratingly addicting, and not until I had all the achievements could I put it away.  As other reviewers have said, it's not really a sim, but a puzzle game.  Figure out where to put your tracks, when to send your trains and pray they don't crash into each other, end up in the wrong station, or heaven forbid, get hit by a passing high speed train.

The gameplay is smooth, and all levels and achievements are obtainable with a little patience.  All in all a highly recommended romp!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042661590', 'num_games_owned': 48, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1449195629}
review:
La combinaciÃ³n perfecta entre un buen juego de Puzzles y el mÃ­tico RailRoad Tycoon. El objetivo es simple, llevar a cada tren a su destino, pero la misiÃ³n complicada, porque tendremos hasta 5 o mÃ¡s trenes a la vez circulando por limitadas vÃ­as, cada escenario comienza de forma simple con solo dos estaciones, pero al final pueden haber 6 o mÃ¡s, debemos estar atentos de cada tren, tener en cuenta los tiempos para no chocarlos, frenar si es necesario, realizar los cambios de agujas en el momento oportuno y ser Ã¡gil con las salidas de trenes sino queremos que los trenes salgan sin aviso.

Si completar cada nivel no es suficiente para nosotros, tenemos retos adicionales que nos propone el propio juego en cada nivel, desde cosas sencillas como evitar choques o destrucciÃ³n de vÃ­as, hasta sacar varios trenes anticipadamente o evitar gastar mÃ¡s de cierta cantidad de dinero, tendremos que estar atentos a todo, construir muy bien nuestras vÃ­as y planear nuestra estrategia si queremos conseguir todos los retos.

Aunque no lo parezca es muy adictivo, entretenido y desafiante, mÃ¡s de una vez reiniciarÃ¡s la partida para replantear tu estrategia, su mayor fallo puede ser la falta de variedad de situaciones, si bien es cierto que en ocasiones habrÃ¡n obstÃ¡culos que tendremos que sortear con puentes y tÃºneles predefinidos o incluso vÃ­as de acceso por las que llegarÃ¡n trenes sin aviso, la variedad de situaciones comienza a estancarse con el paso de los niveles.

Los grÃ¡ficos cumplen aunque no destacan, la jugabilidad es fluida, dando la posibilidad de pausar la partida para pensar bien nuestros movimientos, el sonido es adecuado con melodÃ­as que relajan bastante y sonidos de los trenes apropiados.

[b]Lo mejor:[/b]

- Niveles bastante desafiantes.
- Jugabilidad sencilla y bien implementada.
- GrÃ¡ficos y sonido suficientes.

[b]Lo peor:[/b]

- Puede hacerse un poco corto.
- La relaciÃ³n costo/beneficio puede no ser la mejor.
- La variedad de situaciones es limitada.

[b]CalificaciÃ³n:[/b]

- [b]GrÃ¡ficos: 7
- [b]Sonido: 8
- [b]Jugabilidad: 8

[b]Nota final[/b]: 7.5

Recomendado para aquellos que disfruten de los juegos de puzzles y de juegos de trenes que suelen ser bastante escasos.

review:

[b] KURZREVIEW  [/b]

Train Valley ist ein spaÃŸiges, aber schweres Gelegenheitsspiel, in dem es darum geht, ZÃ¼ge mÃ¶glichst schnell (und ohne UnfÃ¤lle) in die nÃ¤chste Stadt zu schicken. Klingt simpel - ist es allerdings nicht.

[h1] ZÃœGE! [/h1]

Wie der Name schon sagt, geht es in Train Valley um ZÃ¼ge. Es gibt viele Missionen, die verschiedene Anforderungen stellen, beispielsweise muss man 100.000 $ Gewinn machen oder mÃ¶glichst viele zusÃ¤tzliche ZÃ¼ge verwenden. Dadurch bekommt das Spiel etwas Abwechslung. Leider ist Train Valley nicht sehr abwechslungsreich, es gibt unterschiedliche Missionen und es wird schwerer. Das Spiel sieht sehr schÃ¶n aus und der Soundtrack bzw. die Sounds sind auch sehr gelungen. Es ist sehr atmosphÃ¤risch und stimmig. Bugs hatte ich nie. Leider nervt oft der Gleisbau. Der ist zwar gut umgesetzt, allerdings baut man manchmal eine Schiene falsch. Oft muss man mehrere Schienen zerstÃ¶ren und nicht die einzelne. Das verbraucht unnÃ¶tig Geld, Zeit und Nerven, worauf es im Spiel ankommt. 

[h1] [u] Pro & Contra[/u] [/h1]

+Sehr schÃ¶ne und stimmige Grafik
+Passende Sounds und Soundtrack
+Viele Maps
+Keine Bugs oder AbstÃ¼rze

-Wenig Abwechslung
-Manchmal ist der Gleisbau umstÃ¤ndlich

[h1] [u] Wertung [/u] [/h1]

*Es macht viel SpaÃŸ, wird allerdings auf Dauer etwas eintÃ¶nig.

[u] Grafik & Design: 15/20 [/u]

[u] Sound & Musik: 7/10 [/u]

[u] Support: 5/5: [/u]

*Kostenlose Updates und ein gÃ¼nstiges DLC. Die Entwickler antworten oft im Forum.

[u] Spieleinstieg: 4/5: [/u]

*Das meiste ist selbsterklÃ¤rend

[h1] 75/100 [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198072044773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1779, 'last_played': 1460767496}
review:
AnÃ¡lisis del Juego Base y la ExpansiÃ³n Germany

Lee el anÃ¡lisis completo en Areajugones: http://areajugones.es/train-valley/analisis-germany/

Train Valley es un curioso y adictivo tÃ­tulo de gestiÃ³n ferroviaria que lleva en Steam desde el pasado mes de octubre de 2015, con unas notables ventas. Fue desarrollado por solo tres programadores rusos adictos a los trenes (Alexey Davydov, Sergey Dvoynikov y Timofey Shargorodskiy, nombrados a si mismos como Oroboro Games) y editado por el estudio Flazm. Nos plantea una jugabilidad bien sencilla: construir vÃ­as, calcular las rutas entre las diferentes estaciones e intentar no accidentar muchos trenes mientras superamos una serie de objetivos.

Sobre el papel parece sencillo pero la propia gran variedad de sus mapas, unido a su creciente dificultad, sencillo manejo y diferentes Ã©pocas que podemos jugar lo han hecho uno de los juegos de gestiÃ³n de ferrocarriles mÃ¡s llamativos de los Ãºltimos meses. Hoy, con el lanzamiento de su primera expansiÃ³n, ambientada en las frÃ­as tierras de Alemania, lo disgregamos y vemos sus principales novedades mÃ¡s importantes. Â¡Pasajeros al tren!

Manejando el difÃ­cil mundo de la locomociÃ³n

Como hemos comentado, Train Valley es un tÃ­tulo que mezcla la simulaciÃ³n, la gestiÃ³n y los puzles con un notable resultado. Tenemos una serie de mapas que se van desbloqueando a medida que superamos los anteriores y cada uno es bastante mÃ¡s difÃ­cil que el anterior, siendo los primeros simples tutoriales. Solo contamos con cuatro herramientas: la de cambiar la direcciÃ³n del tren en una bifurcaciÃ³n, la de crear nuevas vÃ­as, destruirlas o destruir algunas partes del escenario (como Ã¡rboles o casas) y solicitar una nueva locomotora, lo que cuesta dinero de nuestras arcas pero normalmente otorga bastante recompensa. AdemÃ¡s, muchos objetivos se centran en esta Ãºltima opciÃ³n. TambiÃ©n podemos aumentar la velocidad del juego, aunque igualmente al final de cada aÃ±o en el juego se nos cobran una serie de impuestos, y pausar la partida. Todo muy sencillo e intuitivo.

Ahora bien, crear las diferentes vÃ­as de tren entre las estaciones no es tan sencillo como pareciera ya que aparte de los propios obstÃ¡culos (algunos irrompibles) hay una serie de accidentes geogrÃ¡ficos como lagos, rÃ­os, montaÃ±as, etcÃ©tera, que hay que bordear, teniendo por ejemplo que pasar por los rÃ­os por los puentes que se van creando. Esto unido a la propia gestiÃ³n de los trenes para impedir que choquen o se equivoquen de estaciÃ³n (perdiendo dinero paulatinamente), asÃ­ como su velocidad, que varÃ­a segÃºn su carga, hace que algunos escenarios sean bastante complicados, y requieran numerosos intentos para conseguir todos sus objetivos y, de paso, los numerosos logros que tiene el juego, a cada cual mÃ¡s complicado que el anterior.

A medida que vamos superando las fases se van desbloqueando nuevos mundos, ambientados en diferentes Ã©pocas y lugares, cada uno con sus propias locomotoras y accidentes geogrÃ¡ficos caracterÃ­sticos AsÃ­, por ejemplo, estÃ¡ Europa desde 1830 a 1980, AmÃ©rica desde 1840 a 1960, la USSR desde 1880 a 1980, JapÃ³n desde 1990 a 2020 y, la nueva incorporaciÃ³n del presente DLC: Alemania, que en sus seis nuevos niveles podemos ver importantes eventos de dicho paÃ­s, como la Primera Guerra Mundial, la caÃ­da del Muro de BerlÃ­n o un escenario muy moderno ambientado en el nuevo aeropuerto de Frankfurt. AdemÃ¡s incorpora muchas novedades jugables ya que en un nivel caen bombas del cielo y el de BerlÃ­n es un autentico reto solo apto para los mÃ¡s valientes.

Lee el anÃ¡lisis completo en Areajugones: http://areajugones.es/train-valley/analisis-germany/

author: {'steamid': '76561197987934492', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1812, 'last_played': 1672813101}
review:
Ok, let's get over the misconception first: No matter what the dumb user defined tags say, this is not a sim. This is an active puzzle game, that just happens to involve trains. 

That having been said, it does combine two of my favorite things, trains games and puzzle games. I never thought that I'd somehow have 30 hours in the game, it's something that I just kept on coming back to, having this need to finish all three stamps on all maps, including the DLC.

Personally I love the fact that there's a speed function that lets me play fast and just pause when I need to, it makes for a super great challenge (until they put in no pausing as a stamp requirement in the new DLC that made me sad).

I personally experienced no crashes of any sort, only in the DLC did I have a bit of a bug where the main menu wouldn't pop up if I hit escape, which was basically just a trifling annoyance. 

To sum it up: I love finding little unknown games like this which I end up enjoying way more than I ever thought I would, and I'm highly looking forward to future DLC!

author: {'steamid': '76561198297739789', 'num_games_owned': 45, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1463324504}
review:
Train Valley is a great game if you get really into it. It can be stressing but most of the time it's quite relaxing and if you love management and have some overview skills it's great for you! And one of the best things is that you actually learn managing and keeping your head cool in panicky moments. 

Pro's;
*Challenging
*Not boring at all
*Keeps you playing
*Very fun

Cons;
*Graphics are not optimized (But this can be a good thing if you don't have one of the best computers in the world)
*You're going to lose a lot of time ;)

But I warn you! Once you start the game with the thought "I'm going to play a little bit" it's not a little bit, but like a few hours. Great game! 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198055381563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1602611864}
review:
Fun game - would like more levels and DLC, level editor maybe and some form of sharing them. Bought it recently, would keep playing. *insert obligatory Thomas the Tank Engine and ASDF Movie memes here*

Although hearing the train noises makes me think of an awful pickup line of; "Let me Choo Choo in your Hoo Hoo" 

Nice puzzles though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041810920', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 37, 'playtime_at_review': 1228, 'last_played': 1712421993}
review:
This game have everything to be great:

- Trains!! (For the child within me)
- Relaxing and addictive gameplay
- Linux support
- Linux demo (that is a rare thing)
- Trains!!!
- Easy to learn and not very hard to master
- Have I mentioned trains?

author: {'steamid': '76561197992135430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1588166441}
review:
Same as train valley one this is a excellent train management-come-puzzle game.  It's a game that has been developed with loving care, bugs ironed out and balance made near perfect.
The devs is always on the job and listens to constructive feedback, more than that the dev's will act on player feedback.

The game is fun, very much so.  It's polished and is worth a lot more than the asking price.  They are not greedy and could easily ask twice the price for this game and get it.  Dev's like this deserve your support.

review: Loved the game. The challenge of the puzzle evolves and becomes more difficult as you progess, but there are also awards to gain, that challenge the complexity. The ability to go on unlimited play each level, after you complete the level requirements. I've lost 40 hours to this game, and have stopped since University started again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960283476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1458508335}
review: So, while playing, the game will auto start trains while you are trying to arrive at a station. Makes the annoying at best.  It was fun, but having trains explode as soon as they arrive seems pointless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037741876', 'num_games_owned': 275, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1093, 'last_played': 1585121676}
review:
I got this game thinking it would be like Roller Coaster Tycoon, but found something slightly different. Yes it does require micromanagement, but did not need me to micromange a bunch of things. It need a little more thought in how and where I built tracks and use of my money. It is a nice game to just relax with and if you like to have a podcast or something else going on the side, at least for myself anyway.
      The graphics, while I don't speak for everyone, are nice. They make me feel like a kid playing with a model train set. It almost makes me want to go out and buy a model train set, but this was alot cheeper and had less of the mess. The graphics are not overly intensive but then again there really is no reason they need to be, but that is just my opinion. So I would would be willing to say that a good amount of computers could run this game no problems.
      While I have not completly finished this game I would still say I am willing to recommend this game to a friend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021622691', 'num_games_owned': 449, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1074, 'last_played': 1469903145}
review: Greatly enjoyed playing and completing Train Valley, the simple game concept flows really well and the increasing demands imposed by the levels work effectively to teach new concepts and challenge players. Plus, of course, the art in the game is just beautiful. The only downside are the limited number of levels and the artifical difficulty caused by some design choices, but I hope the developers will keep working to fix these.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963596414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1096, 'last_played': 1461492945}
review:
This is not another Railroad Tycoon type of game.  The main aim for Train Valley is to link a bunch of stations in close proximity and get the trains to the other stations as quickly as possible without them crashing into one another or going to the wrong station (colour coded).  Some also have objectives relating to the number of trains you must run before the time runs out or how much you need to earn (get them to stations quicker and/or run more trains).

This is pretty simply to play, but it requires constant attention  You are constantly fipping track switches to make the trains follow the correct route.  Highly recommended, particularly for casual gamers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023920509', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1457197861}
review:
Tl:DR =  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r1vx0FrwFWE&feature=youtu.be&ab_channel=LORDTRANCER

So i got this game from the the developers to test and make a review. Ill be honest its to much like a facebook game! Its too casual and i enjoy casual games. For this game it should be alot cheaper, i do think there are ways to improve the game. You can listen to my thoughts on this on the video above, but over all i beleive it is to expensive for what it is, its to casual and its not engaging, biggest improvement that could be made is making the stations to be able to be deployed where every you like instead of static locations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257053544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1595206648}
review:
Train Valley is a great game to play if you're looking for a casual train simulation/railroad builder. My only complaint is that there are fewer levels then I expected, but since the game is constantly getting updated, there should be more levels soon.

The game has 2 modes: Regular & Sandbox. In Regular Mode you have to watch your money and make sure to dispatch all the trains as quick as you can. In Sandbox Mode there are no limits. You can do whatever you want.

My rating: 8.7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198084488796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1528012865}
review:
I do really like this game, I like the challenge. However, there can be times where it's very frustrating because you may need to do some levels over and over again to get past them. Train Valley is about bulding train tracks from one station to another, and getting trains into the correct station.
Having a quick look in the settings, there is also a color blind mode in there, so if you need that option, they've added it for you!

SIMULAR GAMES: If you like a game on Steam called Mini Metro, you'll most likely like Train Valley. And for the people that remember the 1998 Loco Lego, and you liked the trains there, you MAY also like this game.

RATING: 7/10 - Good game, get it if you like puzzles, making train tracks, organisation and some added frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985941381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1468069614}
review:
This is a fun little train game.  It's economics are exceedingly simple as is the user interface.  

The basic game play is simple.  Lay track, control swiches, send trains to the right stations, don't run trains into each other or off the track.

The challenges, however, can be very difficult.  You may be required to earn a specific minimum amount of money while getting all your dispatches perfect, and doing so will require you to schedule extra trains that you can only just barely get enough routed, while trying to make sure you're switches are all lined up so the trains don't run into each other and end up on the right track.

Some reviewers have said the game is short.  This is true- there are only 24 scenarios and no scenario takes more than an hour.  However, the harder scenarios have great replay value and frankly will take many attempts to master anyway.

For enthusiasts of games like Railroad Tycoon (and I am a HUGE fan myself), this takes train management down several notches to the level of operating your own home layout - which quite frankly is something I've no doubt many people have been longing for because for all the wonderfullness of Railroad Tycoon, what it is NOT is a train dispatcher simulation.  Train Valley is.

Pros:
- Simple interface, simple economics
- You run trains, not companies
- Scenario complexity is just the right level of hard
- Feels like a home train layout vs. a national railroad model

Cons:
- UI needs refinement
- A little cutesy looking
- Feels like a home train layout vs. a national railroad model (yes this could be a pro OR con)

Overall?  4 stars with potential.

review:

The game itself looks decent, though buggy, it just isn't what it looks like it is on the store page.

review:
Este jogo Ã© de arrancar os cabelos. Muito bom, mas tem que haver persistÃªncia. Algumas partes se tornam atÃ© fÃ¡ceis; mas caso seja derrotado, iniciasse da etapa que parou. Mas hÃ¡ umas que por um triz, muitas vezes tem que se repetir para se concluir a faze.

AnimaÃ§Ã£o boa; efeitos idem; som atrativo; manuseio simples de mais, e te prende no desespero quando tudo vai pros ares com um tremendo BOOMM!!!, faltando um tiquinho sÃ³ para concluir a faze. Show, nota 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024119782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 5374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1454547316}
review: Great game and a nice 'puzzle' concept, especially for the price. You can while away many hours with this fun game. The only annoying aspect is, after a very short countdown, one or more trains may leave a station without any control by the player. This wouldn't be so bad if the train could be immediately stopped by the player but the icon does become ready often until it's too late. Of course, that could just be a limitation of my gaming skill but it appears other players have said the same thing. That aside, it's still a lot of fun for $10.00.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092348237', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1454177997}
review: Its a really fun and addictive game, and even if you dont like trains (like me) you might really like this. And i love it, so go check it out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198161616672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1454296294}
review:
This is a really fun micro-managing game. You build tracks and guide trains to their respective stations, tryingto hurry them as fast as you can while also avoiding mistakes such as crashing trains together or delivering them to the wrong station. The goals are fun, and the later levels are actually a lot more challenging than I expected. I think it will still take me a few hours to beat all the levels and collect all of the task badges. 

However, I expected a lot more worldbuilding to be involved. When choosing "Sandbox" mode, you get to chose out of all the levels to center your trains, but you have unlimited money, no tasks, and a very tiny, prebuilt playing field. I honestly bought this game looknig for the worldbuidling aspect, but was pleasently surprised with a different kind of experience. Still, I -really- wish I could build cities, make my own stations, and actually run a rail in a huge environment. Maybe the later levels will resolve this. Still having a lot of fun with it though!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198136295424', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1453666662}
review:
[h1] Notice: This game was sent to me to review by my YouTube network. However, my opinion is not biased and is honest to how I feel ab out the game. [/h1]

Train Valley has been sitting in my Steam Library since October, and I only downloaded it today when I was bored. To my surprise, it's a lot of fun. For the (almost) hour I've played, I have enjoyed every minute. 

[list]
[*]Firstly, Train Valley has an outstanding almost cartoonish art style.

[*]Secondly, The game has a lot of content. With over 24 levels, each lasting about 15 minutes(or longer), there's a lot to get through. Not to mention the Sandbox mode, which allows you play all the aforementioned with unlimited money and other game changing bonuses. 

[*]Thirdly, I enjoyed the sound track. Great ambient music.

[*]Last but not least, Train Valley is extremely well optimised. On the highest settings, I was easily generating way over 60fps. Allowing for an enjoyable, good looking experience.
[/list]

Overall, the game is great. But it's not very original. I've seen these game idea countless times online, usually free too. However, the quality and quantity of content in Train Valley cannot be beaten.

I highly recommend this game and I would of definitely paid the Â£6.99/$9.99 price premium had I not been offered it for free.

[h1] Correction: [/h1] I discovered this game is capped at 60fps, which I was easily maxing out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040147515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 8647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3461, 'last_played': 1520392182}

author: {'steamid': '76561198122916952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1542, 'last_played': 1476295857}
review:
This is a much more refined and polished version of the flash game, Railway Valley. http://railwayvalley.com/
The puzzles are the same, but much more though out. The interface is similar, but much easier to use. If you enjoy Railway Valley, then Train Valley does everything a reboot/sequel should do, it takes what worked and makes it better. 

Highly addictive, and sometimes so frustrating, but that's what makes it fun. It's never so hard you are unsure how it can be done. You can see victory, it's just a rail away.

review: Train Valley ist ein charmanter und kurzweiliger Puzzler, der sich durch die MÃ¶glichkeit zu pausieren und die dadurch entstehende Ruhe von den gÃ¤ngigen Zug-Puzzle-Spielen abhebt. Freunde entsprechender Spiele werden damit 5-10 Stunden gut unterhalten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035523550', 'num_games_owned': 2213, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1001, 'last_played': 1680329706}
review:
Train Valley is a casual real-time puzzle game, with trains as theme.

It's casual as it's 24 levels only takes 10 minutes each to finish, excluding pausing and retries on the harder levels :).
It's a micromanagement game, with your objective to route trains to the correct destination without making them crash or end up at the wrong station.
The puzzle element comes from the challenge of building an optimum track layout that allows many trains to run at the same time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995998723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1451684560}
review: Fun game for a while, and it actually gets quite difficult. In the higher levels you are pressured by both time (you need to deploy extra trains) and by the fact that the trains autostart when you keep them waiting for too long. Haha, I hated this! But it gets boring after a while, the levels look very similar to each other even though they have different names/countries in the menu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002251148', 'num_games_owned': 396, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2585, 'last_played': 1544647462}
review:
The very first thing you should know about this game is that it is [b]not[/b] a business simulation! This is no Railroad Tycoon or Industry Giant. It is more of a micro management focused virtual model railway. If that sounds strange and unconventional to you you might want to check out the free demo first.

The gameplay consists only marginally of financial management and largely of creating track layouts and manual train guidance. The challenge comes from creating connections between set stations and handling an ever growing amount of railway traffic that will put your planning skills to the test. With the help of 3 different game speeds and a pause button at your disposal you can decide yourself how reflex heavy each level will be.

This game is best played in short bursts since each level can be finished within minutes. Yet it maintains a decently high level of replayability, especially for players that like to maximize their efficiency and want to perfect track layouts for optimal capacity.

The level design is appealing and varied with an almost toy-like aesthetic. And the music is appropriately soothing and up-beat. Though it might get repetetive if you decide to 'binge' the game and finish it in one sitting.
Depending on your personal aim in terms of perfection and Highscores that may take you between 5 and 20 hours.

Overall you can expect a very pleasent experience for a rather low price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044090188', 'num_games_owned': 1882, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1557007979}
review: A rather enjoyable real-time micromanagement puzzle game involving trains. Low asking price, high entertainment value.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002302830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1498844206}
review:
Not sure if you've ever played "Sid Meier's Railroads" but it's a much more simplified version of that (and that game was fairly simple to begin with!). Someone also compared it to "Lionel's(?) Train Town" which is also a fair comparison to make!

To start with, it's not a tycoon game so don't be fooled by the images if they look like a Railroad Tycoon. The game is more focused on being a puzzle game based around trains. I'm sure if you've played Railroad Tycoon or the like you've had to overcome complicated junctions or network improvements the puzzles tend to focus on that skill - placing stations in awkward places. 

Every so often the game will general a train which will be at one of the stations (there's a gauge timer thing at the bottom right of the screen so you can see when the next train will generate) - you can also call on addional trains to create additional revenue. The train will be assigned a colour and you have to create a route via the switches/junctions you've made in your solution to get the train to it's destination. Laying track and destroying objects costs money and, along with a tax you have to pay, your balance can deplete quickly - going below 0 results in bankrupcy and you lose the game.

There are four different regions progressing in difficulty. Difficulty in this game is present through awkwardly placed stations, objects to either neogotiate around or destroy and build over at an addition cost (depends on what you destroy for cost) and the challenges present in each level (spend x money, don't let trains go to the wrong stations, etc) create some replayability.

This is a fun puzzler and the trains were just a bonus (well, at least for me anyway).

author: {'steamid': '76561198025143383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1647889307}
review:
Like others have said it isn't a train management game, it's a puzzle game, but it's a really good one. The graphics are great and not too taxing on a system, which means I can start it up and have a quick play in seconds. Dipping in and out is no problem and replaying some of the easier levels takes on a zen-like quality. 

The game is charming, with good music and sound effects and a really great design, essentially like looking at a really good train set!

I was playing on level 9 or so and made a really elegant rail system, so when I didn't notice I had two trains on the same path until too late I literally cried out! All I'm saying is that any game that can get that sort of reaction is a good game. 

My one critisism is that the first time I played my progress was lost because I wasn't syncing to the cloud. But thats a small complaint because it was easy t o fix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052533235', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 915, 'last_played': 1450207025}
review:
Pro's
+ easy gameplay of starting/stopping/reversing trains, setting switches and building new railways
+ the feeling of those near-miss moments, well planned two way railways and "roundabouts"
+ the rocket launch (I didn't even notice it until after it happened)
+ levels change on a restart of the same level

Mixed
- not a lot of different trains; I would've liked more real trains and some sort of collectors book-ish element
- the graphics of the levels; often you're just to busy managing your routes to notice it though

Con's
- the UI; would've been visually easier to have all the elements in the top center
- the menu's look really bad to me, I like the concept of the history book and stamps though
- some special trains are sometimes pushing waiting trains out of the station without notice or countdown timer; happens only on a few levels

Recommended
+ pausing the game while building tracks ;)
+ classical music (for stress relief) playlist via Youtube
+ spending the money you earn on improving your railways (layout)

Still unsure? There's a demo that represents the game well (played that about 3 hours before purchase as well)

author: {'steamid': '76561198012415113', 'num_games_owned': 1129, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1546971819}
review: Need a little game to calm your nerves? [b]That's not Train Valley.[/b] It may look like casual fun, but it gets pretty hectic, pretty soon. Don't get me wrong, i really like it.  It's enjoyable logic/micro-management game. Building tracks, sending trains to right stations, trying not to crush them to each other, trying not to bankrupt... Sounds easy, but when the level becomes filled with trains and you must constantly juggle them ... It can ruin your nerves :) Active pause function helps a bit, but very often one mistake, one delay and you're royally **cked.   Overall, [b]very cool game[/b], but remember - it's not a cakewalk.  Far from it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971589448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1284, 'last_played': 1514395530}
review:
I've been enjoying this puzzle/strategy/simulation game even though it's become taxing as I've got later into the game.

Don't expect A-Train, Transport Tycoon, Railroad tycoon etc as it's not a business simulator in that sense.

The concept is simple, match the trains to their destinations and try to use the shortest routes possible to make sure you get the most money when they arrive, you have to do all this while not bankrupting yourself from building track.

It can get extremely fast paced and you have to keep an eye on how your track switches are orientated as when a train passes it switches them to align with it's path, so it can mess up other trains paths.  Switches can also sometimes be obscured by buildings, so they require careful placement.

Is it worth the price I paid for it? 
Well If you rent a dvd for Â£3.50 it can enterain you for approximately 2 hours, this games priced currently at Â£6.99 and you might notice I've spent a few more hours than that playing, so I've got my moneys worth out of it.  

If I could go back in time and advise myself as to whether I should buy it, I would recommend it to myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999151078', 'num_games_owned': 835, 'num_reviews': 291, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1557528637}
review:
Despite what you may think looking at the store page, this is less of a management sim and more of a straight-up puzzle game, although it does a decent job of simulating a rail network. It's quite a good game too: fun, challenging and pretty to boot. The only train-related complaint I have is that the steam locomotives are often depicted without tenders, but as you'll usually be playing from a birds-eye view, it's not a huge issue.


However, I have to say that Train Valley reminds me of an older train puzzle game, one near and dear to my heart: [url=http://www.xtcabandonware.com/game/2496/3-d-ultra-lionel-train-town-deluxe]3D Ultra Lionel TrainTown[/url], developed in 2000 by Dynamix. That game focused on completing missions and solving puzzles, while in Train Valley your main goal is to simply survive until the end of a level without going bankrupt, although completing side goals earns you stamps of recognition. 

Train Valley has players reenact a more realistic depiction of railroading history - although it's mainly in the background - all the while attempting to stay afloat and expand to meet the needs of industry. Players take the role of trainmaster and planner, building tracks and then routing trains to their intended destination.

TrainTown has you manually hauling freight such as ore to smelters, hamburgers to grills, or numbers to multiplication equations. It plays its Lionel model train aesthetic to the hilt and is definitely "wackier", if you're into that sort of thing. Controlling multiple locomotives at the same time is only something you might need to do in the later levels; although it's possible in every level, you don't really need to in the early game.

In TrainTown, [i]one[/i] crash fails a level, and some of those levels were as complex as any you may find in Train Valley. I mean, if the first set of levels was intended for elementary school kids, the last set was probably meant for those with associates degrees. I feel comfortable in saying TrainTown is harder, but satisfying to play as well.

(Incidentally, Train Valley's gameplay is also reminiscent of levels in Railroad Tycoon 2 & 3 where you simply had to route trains across a rail network, as opposed to building a profitable railroad company.)


I know this is a recommendation for Train Valley, which I absolutely recommend for puzzle and train fans, but if you like it I'd say you should give TrainTown a shot too. It's more or less abandonware at this point anyway, no harm in trying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073094447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1553538685}
review:
I love this game. When I say I love I mean: I'm at my office, trying to work and this game is whispering me nice words. 3 minutes later I'm at my desk creating the best train system in the whole fucking valley. I am kind of obsessed with it.
It's relaxing and yet infuriating at the same time. It makes you love trains and hate trains.
It gives you confidence with velocity, but it's exhausting how your confidence is your worst enemy.
Not enough levels. It has plenty of levels but I want more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031200400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1447748525}
review:
Price point score $2.50 Potential $60
First it looks nice and the building works well.
There is nothing really to this game. If you have streached it out to two hours you will see everything it has to offer. The sand box is made for the 4 yr old cousin that bugs you to play. it's so tiny so no pleasure for the building a beutiful thing crowd. the campain is throwing trains at you like there is no such thing as a shedual ever invented. The trains just apear and go after a short time. No time to organize build or repair mistakes. Just throw trains at you till you're broke or broken. This is not a building game nor a train shedual organization sim. So who is this game built for? 4yr ld is not going to like the campain but theres not enough to keep anyone older occupied for more than 20min. So who is this game built for? Why does it get so many unearned recomendations? Is it not finished? Do not try an run this on Windows 10 it is very unstable and a big fight to get it to run.
the potential idea is here for a good game they just haven't put the effort in.

Price point score $2.50 
Potential $60

I now rank my games for it's price point and potential price point. the point at which a game is worth taking the risk on, as in condition. What the game is worth to me to buy. Also the potential price.  The price it would be worth when the game is fully realized and functioning. What the game would be worth to me if what potential i see in it gets completed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017706666', 'num_games_owned': 1228, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 1173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 876, 'last_played': 1469758898}
review:
[h1]A Paladinâ€™s Review: Train Valley. Cursing at Train Switches from 1830 to 2020.[/h1]
[list]
[*]Genre: Indie Micromanagement Puzzle Game. 
[*]Developed and Published by: Oroboro Games & Flazm.
[*]Platform: Windows, MacOSX and Linux.
[*]Business Model: Base Game + Upcoming DLC
[*][i]Copy Purchased by Myself[/i] 
[/list]
[i][url=http://kingisaaclinksr.com/2015/11/07/a-paladins-review-train-valley-cursing-at-train-switches-from-the-1830s-to-the-2020s/]Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/i]

[b]Overall Gameplay Thoughts[/b]
Train Valley, a quirky little title that got a surprising amount of press attention considering this is the publisherâ€™s first game. Are we really that starved for train management styled games that anything that resembles one needs to be checked out? The answer is probably yes. The genre has been forever dominated by Open Train Tycoon, Train Tycoon Deluxe and the like for the past 20 years. Entries into the genre are far and few between, often lacking in quality. Hereâ€™s the thing, Train Valley isnâ€™t a management game in the traditional sense. Not by a long shot. This is more of a puzzle game where the single objective is to figure out how to solve the level without running out of cash and subsequently going bankrupt. Everything else is a secondary concern.

On the surface, it looks like a simple micromanagement game and it is but thereâ€™s some mechanics woven in to make the experience more interesting. All youâ€™ll be doing is deploying trains, building track and managing switches. During the level, trains need to be deployed and delivered to their destination station as soon as possible for a couple of reasons: each train has a money value, thatâ€™s rewarded to the player upon completion, which slowly deteriorates over time. Additionally, trains will launch automatically from the station after a certain amount of time. The only warning youâ€™ll get is a five second notification before they launch. So, you need to make sure that stations are regularly deploying trains to prevent any accidents from occurring. This is made more complicated by the levels themselves which will spawn additional stations which need to be connected to the rest of the line and increasingly faster trains. Furthermore, thereâ€™s an in-game annual tax that you have to make sure to have money for. So, avoid being greedy or risk losing the level. Finally, as time passes, buildings will crop up over time that you may need to maneuver around or destroy (costing a lot of money).

[b]Content Thoughts[/b]
There are four chapters in total that are centered around a particular nation (or group of nations) that create the overall theme for each level and the trains youâ€™ll see. This includes Europe, the United States, Russia and Japan. Over the course of each chapter, the levels will transition from the early 1830s to the modern age of 2020 while featuring a certain time era for that nation in the level. This changes what the trains look like as well. In terms of how it affects mechanics, the changing of time will increase the length of the trains and make them faster. For each chapter, thereâ€™s five challenge levels and one score attack level. Each challenge level also comes with the option to continue the level forever once youâ€™ve finished it. For each level, thereâ€™s three optional goals you can try to shoot for and you donâ€™t have to get all of them in one go. These goals can range from never wrecking a train, to gaining a certain amount of money to not allowing a train arrive at the wrong destination. They can be challenging to acquire, especially the gaining X amount of money, and may require several redos. I recommend trying to finish one of them during a level because theyâ€™ll add challenge to the levels and give them their own personality. It would have been nice if the achievements you had already completed were marked as such but itâ€™s not a big deal. The score attack level is the culmination of the entire chapter. It plays the entire time period for the nation in one go from 1800s to 2000s while also doubling the in-game speed. This can be very tricky to deal with as it means taxes come twice as fast even though your trains stay at the same speed. Good luck on the Japan level, itâ€™s brutally difficult.

[b]PC Settings[/b]
Settings for Train Valley are decent, if limited. Video settings only include two sliders for resolutions and quality. Youâ€™ll probably run the quality at â€œfantasticâ€ unless youâ€™re trying to run this off a toaster. Resolution choices seem pretty good and it maxes out at the monitorâ€™s resolution. The game has a cheap 3D look to it so itâ€™s not like thereâ€™s any options missing. Fullscreen on/off and colorblind mode are included as well. Thereâ€™s only two sound slider options for effects and music. Youâ€™ll probably end up turning music off quickly because it is quite awful. That definitely could have used some more work. Rebindable keys with secondary buttons are here for every control as well. The game also supports multiple languages.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
Iâ€™ve been looking for a lighter train management experience like Train Valley for some time and their timing was lucky. The game looks cheap both mechanically and visually but itâ€™s got a surprising amount of depth to keep the player engaged throughout the four chapters. Their asking price is right on the money in my opinion. Biggest issues I have with Train Valley are the music and sandbox mode. The music is awful, repetitive and not fun to listen to. The sandbox mode basically gives you unlimited resources to do whatever you want but thereâ€™s not a lot of flexibility to do anything crazy, so I donâ€™t think youâ€™ll use it much. For a bit of micromanagement fun to play every now and again, Train Valley works and plays well. The four chapters are challenging enough that you wonâ€™t blitz right through them and playing for the achievements will give you even more playtime. An enjoyable, if light, indie game.

[h1][url=http://wp.me/p4fZDz-2tn]Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/h1]

review:
A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b99sE4QFBhg

Surprisingly addictive and relaxing with depth and strategy. Build railroads in order to connect cities, tunnels and bridges. New railways are cheap when laid across bare fields, but can be expensive when demolishing forests, villages and other existing structures. - Highly Recommended!
